paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: From fairest creatures we desire increase,$NEWLINE$That thereby beauty’s rose might never die,$NEWLINE$But as the riper should by time decease$NEWLINE$His tender heir might bear his memory.$NEWLINE$But thou, contracted to thine own bright eyes,$NEWLINE$Feed’st thy light’s flame with self-substantial fuel,$NEWLINE$Making a famine where abundance lies,$NEWLINE$Thyself thy foe, to thy sweet self too cruel.$NEWLINE$Thou that art now the world’s fresh ornament$NEWLINE$And only herald to the gaudy spring,$NEWLINE$Within thine own bud buriest thy content,$NEWLINE$And, tender churl, mak’st waste in niggarding.$NEWLINE$Pity the world, or else this glutton be,$NEWLINE$To eat the world’s due, by the grave and thee.
paragraphs.translated: We want the most beautiful people to have children, so their beauty will be preserved forever—when the parent dies, the child he leaves behind will remind us of his beauty. But you, in love with your own pretty eyes, are letting your beauty burn itself out. You’re starving the world of your beauty rather than spreading the wealth around. You’re acting like your own worst enemy! Right now you’re the best-looking thing in the world, the only person as beautiful as springtime. But your beauty is like a new bud, and you’re letting it die before it can develop and bring you true happiness. You’re a young man, but you act like an old miser—you’re wasting your beauty by hoarding it and keeping it to yourself! Take pity on the rest of us, or this is how you’ll be remembered: as the greedy pig who hogged his own beauty and took it with him to the grave.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: When forty winters shall besiege thy brow$NEWLINE$And dig deep trenches in thy beauty’s field,$NEWLINE$Thy youth’s proud livery, so gazed on now,$NEWLINE$Will be a tattered weed, of small worth held.$NEWLINE$Then being asked where all thy beauty lies,$NEWLINE$Where all the treasure of thy lusty days,$NEWLINE$To say within thine own deep-sunken eyes$NEWLINE$Were an all-eating shame and thriftless praise.$NEWLINE$How much more praise deserved thy beauty’s use$NEWLINE$If thou couldst answer, “This fair child of mine$NEWLINE$Shall sum my count and make my old excuse,”$NEWLINE$Proving his beauty by succession thine.$NEWLINE$This were to be new made when thou art old,$NEWLINE$And see thy blood warm when thou feel’st it cold.
paragraphs.translated: When forty years have gone by and carved deep wrinkles in your forehead, your youthful beauty, which everyone likes to look at now, will be worth little. Then, when someone asks you where all your beauty is—all the treasure of your virile youth—if you were to say that it’s all there in your withered face and sunken eyes, that would be an all-consuming shame and nothing to be proud of. You’d have a much better excuse if, decades from now, you could say you spent your beauty and youth raising a child. If someone were to ask you why you looked so old, you could say, “The effort I spent raising this beautiful child explains the sorry old state I’m in”—and meanwhile your child’s beauty would be a new incarnation of your own! Having a beautiful child would be like being born again in old age, with the blood that flows coldly in your old veins becoming warm again in his.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Look in thy glass and tell the face thou viewest,$NEWLINE$Now is the time that face should form another,$NEWLINE$Whose fresh repair if now thou not renewest,$NEWLINE$Thou dost beguile the world, unbless some mother.$NEWLINE$For where is she so fair whose uneared womb$NEWLINE$Disdains the tillage of thy husbandry?$NEWLINE$Or who is he so fond will be the tomb$NEWLINE$Of his self-love, to stop posterity?$NEWLINE$Thou art thy mother’s glass, and she in thee$NEWLINE$Calls back the lovely April of her prime;$NEWLINE$So thou through windows of thine age shalt see,$NEWLINE$Despite of wrinkles, this thy golden time.$NEWLINE$But if thou live remembered not to be,$NEWLINE$Die single and thine image dies with thee.
paragraphs.translated: Look in your mirror and tell the face you see that it’s time to father a child. Your face is fresh and healthy now, but if you don’t reproduce it, you’ll be cheating the world and cursing a woman who would happily be your child’s mother. After all, do you think there’s a woman out there so beautiful that she’d refuse to have your child? And what man would be so foolish as to allow his own self-absorption to stop himself from fathering children? You are like a mirror to your own mother, and when she looks at you she can gaze back at the lovely springtime of her youth. In the same way, when you are old and wrinkled, you’ll be able to look at your child and see yourself in your prime. But if you choose not to have a child to remember you, you’ll die alone and leave no memory of your own image.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Unthrifty loveliness, why dost thou spend$NEWLINE$Upon thyself thy beauty’s legacy?$NEWLINE$Nature’s bequest gives nothing, but doth lend,$NEWLINE$And, being frank, she lends to those are free.$NEWLINE$Then, beauteous niggard, why dost thou abuse$NEWLINE$The bounteous largess given thee to give?$NEWLINE$Profitless usurer, why dost thou use$NEWLINE$So great a sum of sums yet canst not live?$NEWLINE$For having traffic with thyself alone,$NEWLINE$Thou of thyself thy sweet self dost deceive.$NEWLINE$Then how when nature calls thee to be gone,$NEWLINE$What acceptable audit canst thou leave?$NEWLINE$Thy unused beauty must be tombed with thee,$NEWLINE$Which usèd lives th' executor to be.
paragraphs.translated: You wasteful lovely person, why are you spending all of your beauty on yourself? Nature doesn’t give us anything; she only lends us the gifts we get at birth, and, being generous herself, she lends the most to people who are generous themselves. So, you beautiful miser, why do you abuse the bountiful gifts that were given to you to share with others? Why do you insist on being such a bad investor, using up the immense treasure you have to offer the world but unable to support yourself or preserve your memory? By only having dealings with yourself, you’re cheating yourself out of the best part of yourself. Then how, when nature says it’s time for you to go, will you be able to give an acceptable account of how you spent your time and beauty? Your unused beauty will have to be buried with you. But if you used that beauty now, it would stay behind once you were gone and preserve your legacy.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Those hours that with gentle work did frame$NEWLINE$The lovely gaze where every eye doth dwell$NEWLINE$Will play the tyrants to the very same$NEWLINE$And that unfair which fairly doth excel.$NEWLINE$For never-resting time leads summer on$NEWLINE$To hideous winter and confounds him there,$NEWLINE$Sap checked with frost and lusty leaves quite gone,$NEWLINE$Beauty o'er-snowed and bareness everywhere.$NEWLINE$Then were not summer’s distillation left,$NEWLINE$A liquid prisoner pent in walls of glass,$NEWLINE$Beauty’s effect with beauty were bereft,$NEWLINE$Nor it nor no remembrance what it was.$NEWLINE$But flowers distilled, though they with winter meet,$NEWLINE$Leese but their show; their substance still lives sweet.
paragraphs.translated: The same process that over time shaped your wonderful face, so that now everybody loves to look at you, will eventually destroy that face, making ugly what is now surpassingly beautiful. For never-resting Time takes summer by the hand, leads him into horrifying winter, and destroys him there—freezing his sap, removing his full leaves, covering up his beauty with snow, and turning everything bare. If we didn’t have perfume distilled from summer flowers to keep in a jar, the effects of summer would vanish at the end of the season. Without perfume, we’d have no way of remembering the summer itself or its beauty. But the flowers used to make perfume lose only their outward beauty when winter comes; their beautiful scent lives on sweetly.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Then let not winter’s ragged hand deface$NEWLINE$In thee thy summer, ere thou be distilled.$NEWLINE$Make sweet some vial; treasure thou some place$NEWLINE$With beauty’s treasure, ere it be self-killed.$NEWLINE$That use is not forbidden usury$NEWLINE$Which happies those that pay the willing loan;$NEWLINE$That’s for thyself to breed another thee,$NEWLINE$Or ten times happier, be it ten for one.$NEWLINE$Ten times thyself were happier than thou art,$NEWLINE$If ten of thine ten times refigured thee.$NEWLINE$Then what could death do if thou shouldst depart,$NEWLINE$Leaving thee living in posterity?$NEWLINE$Be not self-willed, for thou art much too fair$NEWLINE$To be death’s conquest and make worms thine heir.
paragraphs.translated: (Continuing from Sonnet 5) So don’t let wintry old age destroy your summer beauty before your essence has been preserved. Make some woman pregnant and pass on your beauty before it dies with you. It’s unfair to charge exorbitant interest on a loan. But if you lend a woman your body, she’ll be only too happy to pay you back with a child. Having a child—making another version of yourself—will make you happy. Having ten children will make you ten times as happy. What power would death have over you if you left children behind to keep your legacy alive? Don’t be willful and selfish—you’re much too beautiful to be conquered by death, with nothing left of you but a corpse devoured by worms.$NEWLINE$(Continuing from Sonnet 5)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Lo, in the Orient when the gracious light$NEWLINE$Lifts up his burning head, each under eye$NEWLINE$Doth homage to his new-appearing sight,$NEWLINE$Serving with looks his sacred majesty;$NEWLINE$And having climbed the steep-up heavenly hill,$NEWLINE$Resembling strong youth in his middle age,$NEWLINE$Yet mortal looks adore his beauty still,$NEWLINE$Attending on his golden pilgrimage.$NEWLINE$But when from highmost pitch, with weary car,$NEWLINE$Like feeble age he reeleth from the day,$NEWLINE$The eyes, 'fore duteous, now converted are$NEWLINE$From his low tract and look another way.$NEWLINE$So thou, thyself out-going in thy noon,$NEWLINE$Unlooked on diest unless thou get a son.
paragraphs.translated: When the gracious light of the sun rises in the east, each person on earth pays homage to it by gazing upon all its sacred majesty. And even at noon, once the sun has climbed the steep path to the top of the sky, it still looks like a strong young man in his prime and human beings still adore its beauty, watching it pass on its way like a golden king making a pilgrimage. But when the sun grows weary and falls from its highest point, it reels like an old man, and the people who once looked up at it so dutifully stop looking and turn the other way. In the same way, you, wasting your sexual energy in the prime of your life, will die alone and unloved unless you father a son.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Music to hear, why hear’st thou music sadly?$NEWLINE$Sweets with sweets war not, joy delights in joy.$NEWLINE$Why lov’st thou that which thou receiv’st not gladly,$NEWLINE$Or else receiv’st with pleasure thine annoy?$NEWLINE$If the true concord of well-tuned sounds,$NEWLINE$By unions married, do offend thine ear,$NEWLINE$They do but sweetly chide thee, who confounds$NEWLINE$In singleness the parts that thou shouldst bear.$NEWLINE$Mark how one string, sweet husband to another,$NEWLINE$Strikes each in each by mutual ordering,$NEWLINE$Resembling sire and child and happy mother,$NEWLINE$Who all in one, one pleasing note do sing;$NEWLINE$Whose speechless song, being many, seeming one,$NEWLINE$Sings this to thee: “Thou single wilt prove none.”
paragraphs.translated: You’re like music to listen to, so why does listening to music make you sad? Delightful and joyful things should complement one another. So why do you love things that make you unhappy and enjoy things that are bad for you? If music played well and in tune sounds bad to you, it’s because that music is rebuking you for not playing your own part—not making your own harmony—by getting married and having children. Notice how the sound of two strings vibrating together in harmony is like a father and child and happy mother, who all sing one pleasing note together. Though their music has no words, the unity of their voices sings this warning to you: If you stay single, you’ll be a childless nobody.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Is it for fear to wet a widow’s eye$NEWLINE$That thou consum’st thyself in single life?$NEWLINE$Ah, if thou issueless shalt hap to die,$NEWLINE$The world will wail thee like a makeless wife;$NEWLINE$The world will be thy widow and still weep,$NEWLINE$That thou no form of thee hast left behind,$NEWLINE$When every private widow well may keep,$NEWLINE$By children’s eyes, her husband’s shape in mind.$NEWLINE$Look what an unthrift in the world doth spend$NEWLINE$Shifts but his place, for still the world enjoys it;$NEWLINE$But beauty’s waste hath in the world an end,$NEWLINE$And kept unused, the user so destroys it.$NEWLINE$No love toward others in that bosom sits$NEWLINE$That on himself such murd'rous shame commits.
paragraphs.translated: Are you eating up your own life by remaining single because you’re afraid your widow will cry when you die? Ah, if you happen to die childless, the entire world will mourn for you like a wife who’s lost her husband. The world will be your widow and weep forever about the fact that you didn’t leave a copy of yourself. But if you had left a wife behind, she’d have had her children to look at and remind her of her husband. A person who wastes his money is just shifting money around—at least the money’s still in the world. But if beauty is wasted, the world loses it forever: If a beautiful person doesn’t use his beauty, he destroys it. The person who would commit such a murderous outrage on himself has no love in his heart for others.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: For shame deny that thou bear’st love to any,$NEWLINE$Who for thyself art so unprovident.$NEWLINE$Grant if thou wilt, thou art belov’d of many,$NEWLINE$But that thou none lov’st is most evident;$NEWLINE$For thou art so possessed with murd'rous hate$NEWLINE$That ‘gainst thyself thou stick’st not to conspire,$NEWLINE$Seeking that beauteous roof to ruinate$NEWLINE$Which to repair should be thy chief desire.$NEWLINE$O change thy thought, that I may change my mind.$NEWLINE$Shall hate be fairer lodged than gentle love?$NEWLINE$Be as thy presence is, gracious and kind,$NEWLINE$Or to thyself at least kind-hearted prove.$NEWLINE$Make thee another self for love of me,$NEWLINE$That beauty still may live in thine or thee.
paragraphs.translated: If you have any sense of shame, admit that you don’t have any love in your heart for anyone, since you’re so unwilling to care about yourself. I’ll admit, if you like, that many people love you, but it’s also obvious that you love no one. For you are so possessed with murderous hatred that you have no problem plotting against yourself, seeking to destroy the house that you should want to repair. Oh, change your way of thinking, so I can change my mind about you. Should hate have a more beautiful home than love? Be gracious and kind, like your appearance—or at least be kind-hearted to yourself. Have a child out of love for me, so your beauty will live on in your children, if not in you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: As fast as thou shalt wane, so fast thou grow’st$NEWLINE$In one of thine, from that which thou departest;$NEWLINE$And that fresh blood which youngly thou bestow’st$NEWLINE$Thou mayst call thine when thou from youth convertest.$NEWLINE$Herein lives wisdom, beauty, and increase;$NEWLINE$Without this, folly, age, and cold decay.$NEWLINE$If all were minded so, the times should cease,$NEWLINE$And threescore year would make the world away.$NEWLINE$Let those whom nature hath not made for store,$NEWLINE$Harsh, featureless, and rude, barrenly perish.$NEWLINE$Look whom she best endowed, she gave the more,$NEWLINE$Which bounteous gift thou shouldst in bounty cherish.$NEWLINE$She carved thee for her seal, and meant thereby$NEWLINE$Thou shouldst print more, not let that copy die.
paragraphs.translated: As fast as you will decline, you could grow again just as fast, through one of your children. The youth and vigor that you would pass on to a child now that you’re still young, you could call your own when you’re no longer young. In marriage and childbirth lie wisdom, beauty, and reproduction. Without them you have only foolishness, age, and the cold decay of death. If everyone thought like you, the human race would end, and in sixty years there’d be no more world. Let the people who aren’t good enough to preserve—the rough, ugly, poor people—die childless. Nature gave abundantly to the people whom she endowed with beauty, and you should cherish her gifts by being generous with them. Nature made you her stamp, to serve as a template for all human beauty. She meant for you to make copies of yourself, so that the original—you—wouldn’t die.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: When I do count the clock that tells the time,$NEWLINE$And see the brave day sunk in hideous night;$NEWLINE$When I behold the violet past prime,$NEWLINE$And sable curls all silvered o'er with white;$NEWLINE$When lofty trees I see barren of leaves,$NEWLINE$Which erst from heat did canopy the herd,$NEWLINE$And summer’s green all girded up in sheaves$NEWLINE$Borne on the bier with white and bristly beard;$NEWLINE$Then of thy beauty do I question make,$NEWLINE$That thou among the wastes of time must go,$NEWLINE$Since sweets and beauties do themselves forsake$NEWLINE$And die as fast as they see others grow,$NEWLINE$And nothing 'gainst Time’s scythe can make defense$NEWLINE$Save breed to brave him when he takes thee hence.
paragraphs.translated: When I look at the clock and notice time ticking away, and see splendid day sink into hideous night; when I see the violet wilt and curly black hair turn white with age; when I see tall trees that once provided shade for herds now barren of leaves, and the summer’s crops tied up and hauled to the barn as if summer itself were an old man being carried off to his grave—then I have doubts about the fate of your beauty, since you too will have to undergo the ravages of time. Sweet and beautiful creatures don’t stay that way; they die as fast as they see others grow. And there’s no defense against Time’s destructive power, except perhaps to have children—to defy Time when he takes you away.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: O that you were yourself! But, love, you are$NEWLINE$No longer yours than you yourself here live.$NEWLINE$Against this coming end you should prepare,$NEWLINE$And your sweet semblance to some other give.$NEWLINE$So should that beauty which you hold in lease$NEWLINE$Find no determination; then you were$NEWLINE$Yourself again after yourself’s decease,$NEWLINE$When your sweet issue your sweet form should bear.$NEWLINE$Who lets so fair a house fall to decay,$NEWLINE$Which husbandry in honor might uphold$NEWLINE$Against the stormy gusts of winter’s day$NEWLINE$And barren rage of death’s eternal cold?$NEWLINE$O, none but unthrifts, dear my love you know,$NEWLINE$You had a father; let your son say so.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, how I wish you were yourself! But, my love, your identity will only last as long as you’re alive. You should make preparations in anticipation of your inevitable death and pass on your beautiful appearance to someone else. That way, your beauty, which you’ve only borrowed, wouldn’t have to end. Then, even after you died, your beautiful body would be renewed in your children. Who would let such a beautiful house fall into disrepair when prudent maintenance might make it outlast the stormy gusts of winter and the frustrating barrenness surrounding death? Only the most irresponsible spender could do such a thing, you know, my dear love. You had a father—let your son be able to say the same.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Not from the stars do I my judgment pluck,$NEWLINE$And yet methinks I have astronomy,$NEWLINE$But not to tell of good or evil luck,$NEWLINE$Of plagues, of dearths, or seasons' quality;$NEWLINE$Nor can I fortune to brief minutes tell,$NEWLINE$Pointing to each his thunder, rain, and wind,$NEWLINE$Or say with princes if it shall go well,$NEWLINE$By oft predict that I in heaven find;$NEWLINE$But from thine eyes my knowledge I derive,$NEWLINE$And, constant stars, in them I read such art$NEWLINE$As truth and beauty shall together thrive,$NEWLINE$If from thyself to store thou wouldst convert;$NEWLINE$Or else of thee this I prognosticate:$NEWLINE$Thy end is truth’s and beauty’s doom and date.
paragraphs.translated: I don’t base my judgments on the stars, and yet it does seem to me I know astrology. I can’t foresee good or bad events—predict plagues, famines, or what a season will be like. Nor can I predict down to the minute what each person’s misfortunes are going to be. Nor can I tell princes whether things will go well for them by looking at the heavens. But I can forecast the future by looking in your eyes. I see by those reliable guides that truth and beauty will thrive if you would only pass your attributes on to a child. Otherwise, this is what I predict: When you die, truth and beauty will die with you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: When I consider every thing that grows$NEWLINE$Holds in perfection but a little moment;$NEWLINE$That this huge stage presenteth nought but shows$NEWLINE$Whereon the stars in secret influence commént;$NEWLINE$When I perceive that men as plants increase,$NEWLINE$Cheerèd and checked ev'n by the self-same sky,$NEWLINE$Vaunt in their youthful sap, at height decrease,$NEWLINE$And wear their brave state out of memory;$NEWLINE$Then the conceit of this inconstant stay$NEWLINE$Sets you, most rich in youth, before my sight,$NEWLINE$Where wasteful time debateth with decay,$NEWLINE$To change your day of youth to sullied night;$NEWLINE$And all in war with time for love of you,$NEWLINE$As he takes from you, I engraft you new.
paragraphs.translated: When I think about the fact that every living thing is perfect only for a brief time, that the whole world is one big stage on which the stars secretly control the action; when I see that men grow like plants, encouraged and then thwarted by the same sky, exulting in their youthful vigor and then declining just when they’re at their height, vanishing until their glory is no longer even remembered; when I think about the whole world’s instability—then I think of you, a youth enjoying so many of nature’s rich gifts. In my mind, I see time and decay debating with each other about how to corrupt your sunny youth, how to convert it to old age and night. Out of love for you, I wage war against time: As he takes away your youth, I continually recreate you in these poems.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: But wherefore do not you a mightier way$NEWLINE$Make war upon this bloody tyrant, time,$NEWLINE$And fortify yourself in your decay$NEWLINE$With means more blessèd than my barren rhyme?$NEWLINE$Now stand you on the top of happy hours,$NEWLINE$And many maiden gardens, yet unset,$NEWLINE$With virtuous wish would bear your living flowers,$NEWLINE$Much liker than your painted counterfeit.$NEWLINE$So should the lines of life that life repair$NEWLINE$Which this time’s pencil or my pupil pen$NEWLINE$Neither in inward worth nor outward fair$NEWLINE$Can make you live yourself in eyes of men.$NEWLINE$To give away yourself keeps yourself still,$NEWLINE$And you must live, drawn by your own sweet skill.
paragraphs.translated: (Continuing from Sonnet 15)But why not take advantage of a stronger way to fight against this bloody tyrant, Time, and strengthen yourself in your old age in a happier way than with my useless sonnets? Now your capacity for pleasure is at its peak, and many virtuous maidens would love to marry you and bear your children, who would recreate your image much better than any artificial reproduction such as a painting or poem. The faces of your children will renew your life. Time created you and brought you to your present state of perfection, but it cannot preserve your inner worth or outer beauty, and neither can my poetry. Having a baby would preserve your image and ensure that you live on by your own design.$NEWLINE$(Continuing from Sonnet 15)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Who will believe my verse in time to come$NEWLINE$If it were filled with your most high deserts?$NEWLINE$Though yet heav'n knows it is but as a tomb$NEWLINE$Which hides your life and shows not half your parts.$NEWLINE$If I could write the beauty of your eyes$NEWLINE$And in fresh numbers number all your graces,$NEWLINE$The age to come would say, “This poet lies—$NEWLINE$Such heavenly touches ne'er touched earthly faces.”$NEWLINE$So should my papers, yellowed with their age,$NEWLINE$Be scorned, like old men of less truth than tongue,$NEWLINE$And your true rights be termed a poet’s rage$NEWLINE$And stretchèd meter of an ántique song;$NEWLINE$But were some child of yours alive that time,$NEWLINE$You should live twice: in it and in my rhyme.
paragraphs.translated: Who in the future will ever believe my poetry if I praise you as you deserve? Though, I have to admit, my poetry is like a tomb that actually hides what you are really like and doesn’t manage to show even half of your true qualities. If I could capture in my writing how beautiful your eyes are and create new verses to list all of your wonderful attributes, decades from now people would say, “This poet lies. No human face was ever so divine.” In this way, my poems (yellowed with age), would be scorned, like old men who talk too much without saying anything true, and what is really your due would be dismissed as a poet’s madness, the false verses of an old song. But if some child of yours were still alive then, you would live twice: in the child, and in my poetry.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Shall I compare thee to a summer’s day?$NEWLINE$Thou art more lovely and more temperate.$NEWLINE$Rough winds do shake the darling buds of May,$NEWLINE$And summer’s lease hath all too short a date.$NEWLINE$Sometime too hot the eye of heaven shines,$NEWLINE$And often is his gold complexion dimmed;$NEWLINE$And every fair from fair sometime declines,$NEWLINE$By chance or nature’s changing course untrimmed.$NEWLINE$But thy eternal summer shall not fade,$NEWLINE$Nor lose possession of that fair thou ow’st,$NEWLINE$Nor shall death brag thou wand’rest in his shade,$NEWLINE$When in eternal lines to time thou grow’st.$NEWLINE$So long as men can breathe or eyes can see,$NEWLINE$So long lives this, and this gives life to thee.
paragraphs.translated: Shall I compare you to a summer day? You’re lovelier and milder. Rough winds shake the pretty buds of May, and summer doesn’t last nearly long enough. Sometimes the sun shines too hot, and often its golden face is darkened by clouds. And everything beautiful stops being beautiful, either by accident or simply in the course of nature. But your eternal summer will never fade, nor will you lose possession of your beauty, nor shall death brag that you are wandering in the underworld, once you’re captured in my eternal verses. As long as men are alive and have eyes with which to see, this poem will live and keep you alive.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Devouring Time, blunt thou the lion’s paws,$NEWLINE$And make the earth devour her own sweet brood;$NEWLINE$Pluck the keen teeth from the fierce tiger’s jaws,$NEWLINE$And burn the long-lived phoenix in her blood;$NEWLINE$Make glad and sorry seasons as thou fleet’st,$NEWLINE$And do whate'er thou wilt, swift-footed time,$NEWLINE$To the wide world and all her fading sweets;$NEWLINE$But I forbid thee one most heinous crime:$NEWLINE$O carve not with thy hours my love’s fair brow,$NEWLINE$Nor draw no lines there with thine ántique pen.$NEWLINE$Him in thy course untainted do allow$NEWLINE$For beauty’s pattern to succeeding men.$NEWLINE$Yet do thy worst, old Time; despite thy wrong,$NEWLINE$My love shall in my verse ever live young.
paragraphs.translated: Devouring Time, go ahead and blunt the lion’s paws. Make the earth swallow up her own creatures. Pluck the sharp teeth out of the fierce tiger’s jaws, and burn the long-lived phoenix in its own blood. Make happy and sad times as you fly by, and do whatever you want, swift-footed Time, to the wide world and all its vanishing delights. But I forbid you to commit one heinous crime. Oh, don’t carve wrinkles into my love’s beautiful forehead, and don’t draw lines there with your old pen. Let him pass through time untainted, to serve as the model of beauty for men to come. But do your worst, old Time. Despite your wrongs, my love will stay young forever in my poetry.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: A woman’s face, with nature’s own hand painted,$NEWLINE$Hast thou, the master-mistress of my passion;$NEWLINE$A woman’s gentle heart, but not acquainted$NEWLINE$With shifting change, as is false women’s fashion;$NEWLINE$An eye more bright than theirs, less false in rolling,$NEWLINE$Gilding the object whereupon it gazeth;$NEWLINE$A man in hue, all hues in his controlling,$NEWLINE$Which steals men’s eyes and women’s souls amazeth.$NEWLINE$And for a woman wert thou first created,$NEWLINE$Till nature as she wrought thee fell a-doting,$NEWLINE$And by addition me of thee defeated,$NEWLINE$By adding one thing to my purpose nothing.$NEWLINE$But since she pricked thee out for women’s pleasure,$NEWLINE$Mine be thy love, and thy love’s use their treasure.
paragraphs.translated: Your face is as pretty as a woman’s, but you don’t even have to use makeup—you, the man (or should I say woman?) I love. Your heart is as gentle as a woman’s, but it isn’t cheating like theirs. Your eyes are prettier than women’s, but not as roving—you bless everything you look at. You’ve got the good looks of a handsome man, but you attract both women and men. When Mother Nature made you, she originally intended to make you a woman, but then she got carried away with her creation and screwed me by adding a certainthing that I have no use for. But since she gave you a prick to please women, I’ll keep your love, and they can enjoy your body.$NEWLINE$woman$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$thing

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: So is it not with me as with that muse,$NEWLINE$Stirred by a painted beauty to his verse,$NEWLINE$Who heav'n itself for ornament doth use,$NEWLINE$And every fair with his fair doth rehearse—$NEWLINE$Making a couplement of proud compare$NEWLINE$With sun and moon, with earth and sea’s rich gems,$NEWLINE$With April’s first-born flow'rs, and all things rare$NEWLINE$That heaven’s air in this huge rondure hems.$NEWLINE$O let me, true in love but truly write,$NEWLINE$And then believe me: my love is as fair$NEWLINE$As any mother’s child, though not so bright$NEWLINE$As those gold candles fixed in heaven’s air.$NEWLINE$Let them say more that like of hearsay well;$NEWLINE$I will not praise that purpose not to sell.
paragraphs.translated: I’m not like that other poet who writes about a woman who’s pretty because she wears a lot of makeup. In his verses, he compares her to heaven itself, and to every other beautiful thing—the sun and moon, the rich gems of earth and sea, the first flowers of April, and all the rest of the precious things on the face of the earth. Since I really am in love, I just want to write the truth, and when I do, believe me—my lover is as beautiful as any human being, though maybe not as bright as the stars. Whoever actually likes those love-poem clichés can say more; I’m not trying to sell anything, so I won’t waste time with praise.$NEWLINE$am

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: My glass shall not persuade me I am old$NEWLINE$So long as youth and thou are of one date;$NEWLINE$But when in thee time’s furrows I behold,$NEWLINE$Then look I death my days should expiate.$NEWLINE$For all that beauty that doth cover thee$NEWLINE$Is but the seemly raiment of my heart,$NEWLINE$Which in thy breast doth live, as thine in me.$NEWLINE$How can I then be elder than thou art?$NEWLINE$O therefore, love, be of thyself so wary$NEWLINE$As I, not for myself, but for thee will,$NEWLINE$Bearing thy heart, which I will keep so chary$NEWLINE$As tender nurse her babe from faring ill.$NEWLINE$Presume not on thy heart when mine is slain;$NEWLINE$Thou gav’st me thine not to give back again.
paragraphs.translated: I won’t believe my mirror when it tells me I’m old, as long as you’re still young. But when I see you with wrinkles, then I’ll know death is on its way, because your beauty is as close to my heart as beautiful clothing to a body. Put another way, my heart beats in your chest and yours in mine. But if that’s true, then how can I be older than you? Therefore, my love, take care of yourself just as I will take care of myself, not for my own sake, but because I have your heart inside of me, which I will protect as carefully as a nurse her baby. Don’t expect to get your heart back from me when mine is dead. You gave it to me forever, never to be returned.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: As an unperfect actor on the stage,$NEWLINE$Who with his fear is put besides his part,$NEWLINE$Or some fierce thing replete with too much rage,$NEWLINE$Whose strength’s abundance weakens his own heart;$NEWLINE$So I, for fear of trust, forget to say$NEWLINE$The perfect ceremony of love’s rite,$NEWLINE$And in mine own love’s strength seem to decay,$NEWLINE$O'ercharged with burden of mine own love’s might.$NEWLINE$O let my books be then the eloquence$NEWLINE$And dumb presagers of my speaking breast,$NEWLINE$Who plead for love and look for recompense$NEWLINE$More than that tongue that more hath more expressed.$NEWLINE$O learn to read what silent love hath writ!$NEWLINE$To hear with eyes belongs to love’s fine wit.
paragraphs.translated: Like an actor who hasn’t learned his lines perfectly and forgets his part because of stage fright, or like some raging animal or human whose excessive passion makes it weak, so I, because I can’t trust myself, forget to say the things a lover should say to his darling; just when my love is strongest it seems to be getting weak. So let my writings speak for my heart instead. They plead for love better than I could if I spoke, even if I said more and more eloquently. Oh, read in these silent lines the love I cannot express in speech. Love will give you the insight to read between the lines.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Mine eye hath played the painter and hath steeled$NEWLINE$Thy beauty’s form in table of my heart.$NEWLINE$My body is the frame wherein ’tis held,$NEWLINE$And pérspective it is best painter’s art.$NEWLINE$For through the painter must you see his skill$NEWLINE$To find where your true image pictured lies,$NEWLINE$Which in my bosom’s shop is hanging still,$NEWLINE$That hath his windows glazèd with thine eyes.$NEWLINE$Now see what good turns eyes for eyes have done:$NEWLINE$Mine eyes have drawn thy shape, and thine for me$NEWLINE$Are windows to my breast, wherethrough the sun$NEWLINE$Delights to peep, to gaze therein on thee.$NEWLINE$Yet eyes this cunning want to grace their art;$NEWLINE$They draw but what they see, know not the heart.
paragraphs.translated:
My
eye has acted like a painter and engraved your beautiful image on the canvas of my heart. My body is the frame that holds this picture; to draw that picture with perspective, realistically representing depth, is the highest skill a painter could have. Only via this painter—my eye—can you find the image of you that dwells continually in my heart: Your own eyes are the windows into my heart. Now look at the favors our eyes have done for each other: My eyes have drawn your shape, and your eyes are windows into which I can look to see my own heart, into which the sun also likes to look, taking a peep at your reflection. Yet my eyes lack a certain skill that would grace the others they already have: They can only draw what they see; they don’t see into your heart.$NEWLINE$eye$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Let those who are in favor with their stars$NEWLINE$Of public honor and proud titles boast,$NEWLINE$Whilst I, whom fortune of such triumph bars,$NEWLINE$Unlooked for joy in that I honor most.$NEWLINE$Great princes' favorites their fair leaves spread$NEWLINE$But as the marigold at the sun’s eye,$NEWLINE$And in themselves their pride lies burièd,$NEWLINE$For at a frown they in their glory die.$NEWLINE$The painful warrior famousèd for worth,$NEWLINE$After a thousand victories once foiled,$NEWLINE$Is from the book of honor razèd quite,$NEWLINE$And all the rest forgot for which he toiled.$NEWLINE$Then happy I that love and am belovèd$NEWLINE$Where I may not remove nor be removèd.
paragraphs.translated: Let fortunate people boast about their prizes and their titles, while I—who am not lucky enough to get such rewards—experience unexpected joy in what I honor most: your love. Those courtiers who enjoy high status because they’re the favorites of great princes are like marigolds. They bloom as long as the sun shines on them, but their pride is fragile—one frown will kill them. And once a famous warrior who has painfully endured and won a thousand battles is defeated, he’s stripped of all his honors, and all of the successes that he worked for are forgotten. How much happier am I, who love and am loved in a place I cannot leave and from which others cannot remove me.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Lord of my love, to whom in vassalage$NEWLINE$Thy merit hath my duty strongly knit,$NEWLINE$To thee I send this written embassage,$NEWLINE$To witness duty, not to show my wit.$NEWLINE$Duty so great, which wit so poor as mine$NEWLINE$May make seem bare, in wanting words to show it,$NEWLINE$But that I hope some good conceit of thine$NEWLINE$In thy soul’s thought, all naked, will bestow it.$NEWLINE$Till whatsoever star that guides my moving$NEWLINE$Points on me graciously with fair aspéct$NEWLINE$And puts apparel on my tattered loving,$NEWLINE$To show me worthy of thy sweet respect.$NEWLINE$Then may I dare to boast how I do love thee;$NEWLINE$Till then, not show my head where thou mayst prove me.
paragraphs.translated: My love, I am your absolute servant; your worth compels me to serve you loyally. I’m sending you this message to show my devotion to you, not to show that I can write well. My skills are so poor that I may make my obligation to you, which is great, seem meager. I don’t have the words to express it properly. But I hope that in your heart you’ll form an idea of what I mean and the idea will enrich your sense of what I owe you. When the star that guides me shines on me favorably, giving me the inspiration to dress up my tattered love for you in clever words that prove I’m worthy of your sweet respect—that’s when I’ll dare to boast about how much I love you. Until then, I won’t show my face anywhere that you can put me to the test.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Weary with toil, I haste me to my bed,$NEWLINE$The dear repose for limbs with travail tired;$NEWLINE$But then begins a journey in my head$NEWLINE$To work my mind, when body’s work’s expired.$NEWLINE$For then my thoughts, from far where I abide,$NEWLINE$Intend a zealous pilgrimage to thee,$NEWLINE$And keep my drooping eyelids open wide,$NEWLINE$Looking on darkness which the blind do see.$NEWLINE$Save that my soul’s imaginary sight$NEWLINE$Presents thy shadow to my sightless view,$NEWLINE$Which, like a jewel hung in ghastly night,$NEWLINE$Makes black night beauteous, and her old face new.$NEWLINE$Lo thus by day my limbs, by night my mind,$NEWLINE$For thee, and for myself, no quiet find.
paragraphs.translated: Weary from work, I hasten to my bed, the sweet place of rest for a body tired out from laboring. But then I start to go on a journey in my head, making my mind work after my body’s work is finished. Because when I go to bed, my thoughts begin the trip from where I am, far away from you, to where you are. They keep my weary eyes wide open, staring at the darkness like blind people do. Except, in my imagination, I see your image, though it’s too dark to see anything else. Like a shining jewel hanging in the terrifying night, your image makes that old, black night look beautiful and young. See, because of you, my body does not rest in the daytime and my mind finds no peace at night.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: How can I then return in happy plight$NEWLINE$That am debarred the benefit of rest?$NEWLINE$When day’s oppression is not eased by night,$NEWLINE$But day by night and night by day oppressed?$NEWLINE$And each, though enemies to either’s reign,$NEWLINE$Do in consent shake hands to torture me,$NEWLINE$The one by toil, the other to complain$NEWLINE$How far I toil, still farther off from thee.$NEWLINE$I tell the day to please him thou art bright,$NEWLINE$And dost him grace when clouds do blot the heaven.$NEWLINE$So flatter I the swart-complexioned night,$NEWLINE$When sparkling stars twire not, thou gild’st the even.$NEWLINE$But day doth daily draw my sorrows longer,$NEWLINE$And night doth nightly make grief’s length seem stronger.
paragraphs.translated: (Continuing from Sonnet 27) So how can I return in a cheerful state of mind when I’m prevented from getting any rest? When the oppression I experience during the day isn’t relieved by any sleep at night, but instead my sleepless nights oppress me during the day and my wearisome days oppress me at night? And though day and night are natural enemies, they’ve shook hands and made a bargain to both torture me, the day with labor, the night with thoughts of how far away you are as I labor over thoughts of you. I try to please the day by telling him how bright you are—so bright that you take the sun’s place when clouds cover the sky. In the same way, I use you to flatter black night, telling him how you brighten the evening sky when stars don’t shine. But they both—day and night—only prolong my sorrows, and night by night this prolonged grief grows stronger.$NEWLINE$(Continuing from Sonnet 27)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: When in disgrace with fortune and men’s eyes$NEWLINE$I all alone beweep my outcast state,$NEWLINE$And trouble deaf heav'n with my bootless cries,$NEWLINE$And look upon myself, and curse my fate,$NEWLINE$Wishing me like to one more rich in hope,$NEWLINE$Featured like him, like him with friends possessed,$NEWLINE$Desiring this man’s art, and that man’s scope,$NEWLINE$With what I most enjoy contented least;$NEWLINE$Yet in these thoughts myself almost despising,$NEWLINE$Haply I think on thee, and then my state,$NEWLINE$Like to the lark at break of day arising$NEWLINE$From sullen earth, sings hymns at heaven’s gate.$NEWLINE$For thy sweet love remembered such wealth brings$NEWLINE$That then I scorn to change my state with kings.
paragraphs.translated: When I’m in disgrace with everyone and my luck has deserted me, I sit all alone and cry about the fact that I’m an outcast, and bother God with useless cries, which fall on deaf ears, and look at myself and curse my fate, wishing that I had more to hope for, wishing I had this man’s good looks and that man’s friends, this man’s skills and that man’s opportunities, and totally dissatisfied with the things I usually enjoy the most. Yet, as I’m thinking these thoughts and almost hating myself, I happen to think about you, and then my condition improves—like a lark at daybreak rising up and leaving the earth far behind to sing hymns to God. For when I remember your sweet love, I feel so wealthy that I’d refuse to change places even with kings.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: When to the sessions of sweet silent thought$NEWLINE$I summon up remembrance of things past,$NEWLINE$I sigh the lack of many a thing I sought,$NEWLINE$And with old woes new wail my dear time’s waste.$NEWLINE$Then can I drown an eye unused to flow,$NEWLINE$For precious friends hid in death’s dateless night,$NEWLINE$And weep afresh love’s long since cancelled woe,$NEWLINE$And moan th' expense of many a vanished sight.$NEWLINE$Then can I grieve at grievances foregone,$NEWLINE$And heavily from woe to woe tell o'er$NEWLINE$The sad account of fore-bemoanèd moan,$NEWLINE$Which I new pay as if not paid before.$NEWLINE$But if the while I think on thee, dear friend,$NEWLINE$All losses are restored, and sorrows end.
paragraphs.translated: When I sit alone in silence and remember the past, I get depressed about all the things I don’t have that I once strived for, and I add to old griefs new tears for all the valuable time I’ve wasted. Then I can drown my eyes, which are not usually wet from crying, in tears for precious friends who are dead, and I can weep again for hurts in loves that are long since over and moan about the loss of many things I’ll never see again. Then I can grieve about grievances I had let go of and sadly recount each woe that I’d already cried about in the past, feeling the pain all over again, as if I hadn’t suffered over these things already. But if I think about you, my dear friend, while I’m doing all of this, I get back everything I’d lost, and all my sorrows end.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Thy bosom is endearèd with all hearts$NEWLINE$Which I, by lacking, have supposèd dead;$NEWLINE$And there reigns love, and all love’s loving parts,$NEWLINE$And all those friends which I thought burièd.$NEWLINE$How many a holy and obsequious tear$NEWLINE$Hath dear religious love stol'n from mine eye$NEWLINE$As interest of the dead, which now appear$NEWLINE$But things removed that hidden in thee lie.$NEWLINE$Thou art the grave where buried love doth live,$NEWLINE$Hung with the trophies of my lovers gone,$NEWLINE$Who all their parts of me to thee did give;$NEWLINE$That due of many now is thine alone.$NEWLINE$Their images I loved I view in thee,$NEWLINE$And thou, all they, hast all the all of me.
paragraphs.translated: You have the love of everyone who used to love me, people who I supposed were dead because I didn’t have their love anymore. Love reigns in your heart—both everything belonging to love and all those friends who I thought were dead and buried. How many tears of devoted love have I shed at funerals, in payment to the dead, when now it appears they had only gone to hide in your heart. You’re like a grave where dead lovers come alive again, decorated with mementos of those lost loves who gave you all the love I owed to each of them. All the love I owed to many is now yours alone. I see these lovers in you, and you, who contain everyone I have ever loved or was loved by, have all of me.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: If thou survive my well-contented day,$NEWLINE$When that churl death my bones with dust shall cover,$NEWLINE$And shalt by fortune once more re-survey$NEWLINE$These poor rude lines of thy deceasèd lover,$NEWLINE$Compare them with the bett'ring of the time,$NEWLINE$And though they be outstripped by every pen,$NEWLINE$Reserve them for my love, not for their rhyme,$NEWLINE$Exceeded by the height of happier men.$NEWLINE$O then vouchsafe me but this loving thought:$NEWLINE$“Had my friend’s muse grown with this growing age,$NEWLINE$A dearer birth than this his love had brought$NEWLINE$To march in ranks of better equipage.$NEWLINE$But since he died and poets better prove,$NEWLINE$Theirs for their style I’ll read, his for his love.”
paragraphs.translated: If you survive me, living on after dust covers my bones, and you should happen to read over again these poor, crude sonnets written by the man who once loved you, remember that things have improved since my day. So even though any poet today could write better sonnets, keep my poems for the sake of my love, not for my skill, which luckier men have far surpassed. And grant me this loving thought: “If my friend’s inspiration was paired with the advantages today’s poets have, his love would have brought forth better poems than these, to rank alongside those of today’s better poets. But since he died, and poets are better now, I’ll read their poems for their style, his for his love.”

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Full many a glorious morning have I seen$NEWLINE$Flatter the mountain tops with sovereign eye,$NEWLINE$Kissing with golden face the meadows green,$NEWLINE$Gilding pale streams with heavenly alchemy,$NEWLINE$Anon permit the basest clouds to ride$NEWLINE$With ugly rack on his celestial face,$NEWLINE$And from the fórlorn world his visage hide,$NEWLINE$Stealing unseen to west with this disgrace.$NEWLINE$Ev'n so my sun one early morn did shine$NEWLINE$With all triumphant splendor on my brow;$NEWLINE$But out alack, he was but one hour mine;$NEWLINE$The region cloud hath masked him from me now.$NEWLINE$Yet him for this my love no whit disdaineth.$NEWLINE$Suns of the world may stain when heav‘n’s sun staineth.
paragraphs.translated:
I’ve seen many beautiful mornings in which the sun beautifies the mountaintops, kissing the green meadows with its golden face and making streams sparkle as if by magic. But then it suddenly permits the nastiest
clouds to ride across its heavenly face, and it hides from the forlorn world, sneaking off to the west in disgrace. In exactly this way, early one morning my sun shone on my face with triumphant splendor, but alas he was only mine for one hour. The clouds have hidden him from me now. But I don’t fault him for this at all. Golden men like him can disgrace themselves as much as the real sun does.$NEWLINE$clouds$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$my

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Why didst thou promise such a beauteous day$NEWLINE$And make me travel forth without my cloak,$NEWLINE$To let base clouds o'ertake me in my way,$NEWLINE$Hiding thy brav'ry in their rotten smoke?$NEWLINE$'Tis not enough that through the cloud thou break,$NEWLINE$To dry the rain on my storm-beaten face.$NEWLINE$For no man well of such a salve can speak$NEWLINE$That heals the wound and cures not the disgrace.$NEWLINE$Nor can thy shame give physic to my grief;$NEWLINE$Though thou repent, yet I have still the loss.$NEWLINE$The offender’s sorrow lends but weak relief$NEWLINE$To him that bears the strong offense’s cross.$NEWLINE$Ah, but those tears are pearl which thy love sheds,$NEWLINE$And they are rich, and ransom all ill deeds.
paragraphs.translated: Sun, why did you make it look like today was going to be such a beautiful day, so that I went out without my cloak, only to let nasty clouds overtake me on my way, hiding your radiance behind their poisonous mist? It’s not enough that you broke through the clouds and dried the rain off my storm-beaten face, because no man can be satisfied with a cure that heals the physical injury but doesn’t take away the disgrace. Nor does it comfort me that you’re ashamed, because even though you regret what you did, I have still lost out. When someone takes something away from you, their being sorry doesn’t help much. Ah, but those tears you’re shedding out of love for me are like pearls—very valuable ones—and they make up for all your bad deeds.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: No more be grieved at that which thou hast done.$NEWLINE$Roses have thorns, and silver fountains mud;$NEWLINE$Clouds and eclipses stain both moon and sun,$NEWLINE$And loathsome canker lives in sweetest bud.$NEWLINE$All men make faults, and even I in this,$NEWLINE$Authórizing thy trespass with compare,$NEWLINE$Myself corrupting, salving thy amiss,$NEWLINE$Excusing these sins more than these sins are.$NEWLINE$For to thy sensual fault I bring in sense—$NEWLINE$Thy adverse party is thy advocate—$NEWLINE$And 'gainst myself a lawful plea commence.$NEWLINE$Such civil war is in my love and hate$NEWLINE$That I an áccessory needs must be$NEWLINE$To that sweet thief which sourly robs from me.
paragraphs.translated: Don’t be upset anymore about what you did. Everything has its bad side: Roses have thorns, sparkling fountains have mud, the sun and the moon are periodically covered up by clouds and eclipses, and disgusting worms live in the sweetest flowers. All men do bad things—even me, right now: As I excuse your transgression by comparing it to other things, I corrupt myself by making excuses for your misdeeds (more excuses for these little sins than they even require). Because what I’m doing is taking your sins, which were just physical urges, and putting my mind to work on their behalf. The person you’ve hurt is now advocating for you—I’m now pleading the case against myself. I’m so conflicted between love and hate that I can’t resist helping that sweet villain who bitterly injures me every hour.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Let me confess that we two must be twain,$NEWLINE$Although our undivided loves are one.$NEWLINE$So shall those blots that do with me remain$NEWLINE$Without thy help by me be borne alone.$NEWLINE$In our two loves there is but one respect,$NEWLINE$Though in our lives a separable spite,$NEWLINE$Which, though it alter not love’s sole effect,$NEWLINE$Yet doth it steal sweet hours from love’s delight.$NEWLINE$I may not evermore acknowledge thee,$NEWLINE$Lest my bewailèd guilt should do thee shame;$NEWLINE$Nor thou with public kindness honor me,$NEWLINE$Unless thou take that honor from thy name.$NEWLINE$But do not so; I love thee in such sort,$NEWLINE$As, thou being mine, mine is thy good report.
paragraphs.translated: I acknowledge that the two of us have to part, even though we’re united in love. That way I can take those disgraces that we’ve incurred together all onto myself, bearing them without any help from you. Our love for one another gives us common cause, despite this awful situation that forces us apart, which, though it can’t prevent us from being united in love, still robs us of sweet hours of pleasure together. I can never greet you openly again, because my guilt would bring shame upon you. Nor can you ever honor me with public kindness without dishonoring your own reputation. But don’t do that. I love you so much that I value your good reputation as my own.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: As a decrepit father takes delight$NEWLINE$To see his active child do deeds of youth,$NEWLINE$So I, made lame by fortune’s dearest spite,$NEWLINE$Take all my comfort of thy worth and truth.$NEWLINE$For whether beauty, birth, or wealth, or wit,$NEWLINE$Or any of these all, or all, or more,$NEWLINE$Entitled in thy parts do crownèd sit,$NEWLINE$I make my love engrafted to this store.$NEWLINE$So then I am not lame, poor, nor despised,$NEWLINE$Whilst that this shadow doth such substance give$NEWLINE$That I in thy abundance am sufficed,$NEWLINE$And by a part of all thy glory live.$NEWLINE$Look what is best, that best I wish in thee.$NEWLINE$This wish I have; then ten times happy me.
paragraphs.translated: Just as a decrepit father takes pleasure in seeing his active child engaging in youthful activities, so I, whom misfortune has injured and crippled, take all the comfort I can in your good worth and fidelity. For whether beauty, nobility, wealth, and intelligence—or any one of these, or all of them, or more than these—are your princely attributes, I’m attaching my love to them. I’m not lame, poor, or despised, as long as this fantasy of mine lets me take so much satisfaction in your good luck and I can live off part of your glory. Whatever is best, that’s what I wish you to have. Since I have this wish, I’m lucky ten times over.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: How can my muse want subject to invent$NEWLINE$While thou dost breathe, that pour’st into my verse$NEWLINE$Thine own sweet argument, too excellent$NEWLINE$For every vulgar paper to rehearse?$NEWLINE$O give thyself the thanks, if aught in me$NEWLINE$Worthy perusal stand against thy sight.$NEWLINE$For who’s so dumb that cannot write to thee,$NEWLINE$When thou thyself dost give invention light?$NEWLINE$Be thou the tenth muse, ten times more in worth$NEWLINE$Than those old nine which rhymers invocate;$NEWLINE$And he that calls on thee, let him bring forth$NEWLINE$Eternal numbers to outlive long date.$NEWLINE$If my slight muse do please these curious days,$NEWLINE$The pain be mine, but thine shall be the praise.
paragraphs.translated: How could I lack things to write about while you’re alive? You pour inspiration into my poetry by giving me the sweetest subject to write about: yourself—too excellent a subject for ordinary writers to describe. Oh, give yourself the credit if you see anything in my writing that’s worth reading. For who is so speechless that he can’t write to you, when you yourself provide the creative spark? You should be the tenth muse, worth ten times more than those other nine invoked by poets. And whoever calls on you for inspiration, let him write eternal verses, to outlive even the farthest reaches of time. If my little bit of inspiration happens to please today’s demanding readers, the painful work can be mine, but the praise shall be yours.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: O how thy worth with manners may I sing,$NEWLINE$When thou art all the better part of me?$NEWLINE$What can mine own praise to mine own self bring,$NEWLINE$And what is’t but mine own when I praise thee?$NEWLINE$Even for this, let us divided live,$NEWLINE$And our dear love lose name of single one,$NEWLINE$That by this separation I may give$NEWLINE$That due to thee which thou deserv’st alone.$NEWLINE$O absence, what a torment wouldst thou prove,$NEWLINE$Were it not thy sour leisure gave sweet leave$NEWLINE$To entertain the time with thoughts of love,$NEWLINE$Which time and thoughts so sweetly dost deceive,$NEWLINE$And that thou teachest how to make one twain,$NEWLINE$By praising him here who doth hence remain.
paragraphs.translated: How can I celebrate your worth in my poems without appearing conceited, given that you’re my better half? What good does it do me to praise myself—and am I doing anything besides praising myself when I praise you? For this reason, let’s live apart. And though we love each other dearly, let’s lose our common identity; by this separation, I can give you the praise that you deserve by yourself. Oh, absence, you would be such a torment if it weren’t for the fact that you give me the chance to fill up the lonely hours with thoughts of love, which make the time pass so sweetly, and that you teach me how to divide my love and me in two, as I, here, praise my friend while he remains elsewhere.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Take all my loves, my love; yea, take them all.$NEWLINE$What hast thou then more than thou hadst before?$NEWLINE$No love, my love, that thou mayst true love call.$NEWLINE$All mine was thine before thou hadst this more.$NEWLINE$Then if for my love thou my love receivest,$NEWLINE$I cannot blame thee, for my love thou usest.$NEWLINE$But yet be blamed, if thou thyself deceivest$NEWLINE$By wilful taste of what thyself refusest.$NEWLINE$I do forgive thy robb'ry, gentle thief,$NEWLINE$Although thou steal thee all my poverty;$NEWLINE$And yet love knows it is a greater grief$NEWLINE$To bear love’s wrong than hate’s known injury.$NEWLINE$Lascivious grace, in whom all ill well shows,$NEWLINE$Kill me with spites; yet we must not be foes.
paragraphs.translated: Take all my loves, my love—yes, take them all: Take my love for you, take away your love for me, and take a lover from me. What do you have now that you didn’t have before? My love, you haven’t acquired true love, because my true love was yours to begin with, before you took this extra from me. If, instead of accepting my love, you make love to the person, love, I can’t blame you, because you’re only taking advantage of my love. But, you should be blamed if you deceive yourself by taking from one person what you won’t take from another—if you willingly make love to one person while refusing to make love to me. I forgive you for stealing from me, gentle thief, although you’re taking the little I have. And yet every lover knows that it hurts more to be injured by a lover than by an enemy. You, who are gracious even when succumbing to lust, you in whom everything bad looks good—even if you kill me with injuries, let’s not become enemies.$NEWLINE$should

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Those pretty wrongs that liberty commits$NEWLINE$When I am sometime absent from thy heart,$NEWLINE$Thy beauty and thy years full well befits,$NEWLINE$For still temptation follows where thou art.$NEWLINE$Gentle thou art, and therefore to be won;$NEWLINE$Beauteous thou art, therefore to be assailed;$NEWLINE$And when a woman woos, what woman’s son$NEWLINE$Will sourly leave her till he have prevailed?$NEWLINE$Ay me, but yet thou might’st my seat forbear,$NEWLINE$And chide thy beauty and thy straying youth,$NEWLINE$Who lead thee in their riot even there$NEWLINE$Where thou art forced to break a twofold truth:$NEWLINE$Hers by thy beauty tempting her to thee,$NEWLINE$Thine by thy beauty being false to me.
paragraphs.translated: Those charming little infidelities that you commit when I’m away from you for awhile are understandable given your youth and beauty, since you’re continually tempted wherever you go. You’re noble and distinguished, so women see you as a prize catch. You’re beautiful, and therefore women pursue you aggressively. And when a woman is the pursuer, what man will rudely refuse her to get his point across? But, oh my—you might at least stay away from my mistress and keep your beauty and youthful urges in line, as they’re leading you into debauchery, which breaks two bonds: my mistress’s fidelity to me, which your beauty tempts her to break, and your bond with me, which your beauty, again, lets you break.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: That thou hast her it is not all my grief,$NEWLINE$And yet it may be said I loved her dearly;$NEWLINE$That she hath thee is of my wailing chief,$NEWLINE$A loss in love that touches me more nearly.$NEWLINE$Loving offenders, thus I will excuse ye:$NEWLINE$Thou dost love her because thou knowst I love her;$NEWLINE$And for my sake even so doth she abuse me,$NEWLINE$Suff'ring my friend for my sake to approve her.$NEWLINE$If I lose thee, my loss is my love’s gain,$NEWLINE$And losing her, my friend hath found that loss;$NEWLINE$Both find each other, and I lose both twain,$NEWLINE$And both for my sake lay on me this cross.$NEWLINE$But here’s the joy; my friend and I are one;$NEWLINE$Sweet flatt'ry! Then she loves but me alone.
paragraphs.translated: The fact that you now have my mistress isn’t the only reason I’m hurt, though it’s true that I loved her dearly. What makes me cry the most is that now she has you, a loss of love that hurts me even more. You two criminals in love, here’s how I’ll rationalize the pain you’ve caused me: You, friend, love her because you know I love her. And she loves you for the exact same reason, putting up with your praises and lovemaking for my sake, because she knows you’re my friend. If I lose you, it’s a win for my mistress. And if I lose her, you will have found what I’ve lost. Both of the people I love find each other, and I lose them both, and both cause me this pain. But here’s what makes me happy: My friend and I are one person. How gratifying!—It turns out my mistress loves only me.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: When most I wink, then do mine eyes best see,$NEWLINE$For all the day they view things unrespected;$NEWLINE$But when I sleep, in dreams they look on thee,$NEWLINE$And, darkly bright, are bright in dark directed.$NEWLINE$Then thou, whose shadow shadows doth make bright—$NEWLINE$How would thy shadow’s form form happy show$NEWLINE$To the clear day with thy much clearer light,$NEWLINE$When to unseeing eyes thy shade shines so?$NEWLINE$How would, I say, mine eyes be blessèd made$NEWLINE$By looking on thee in the living day,$NEWLINE$When in dead night thy fair imperfect shade$NEWLINE$Through heavy sleep on sightless eyes doth stay?$NEWLINE$All days are nights to see till I see thee,$NEWLINE$And nights bright days when dreams do show thee me.
paragraphs.translated: My eyes work best when I’m asleep, because all day they look at things I don’t care about. When I sleep, my dreaming eyes alight on you and glitter brightly in the dark, having found your bright image there. Given that your shadowy dream-image brightens even the dark, how bright might you appear in daylight, when your own light is so much clearer? How bright, when your shadow shines so brightly to my eyes blinded by darkness? What good would it do my eyes to see you in the daytime when they already look at your beautiful image in the dead of night, as I sleep? Every day is as dark as night until I get to see you again, and every night is as bright as day when I see you in my dreams.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: If the dull substance of my flesh were thought,$NEWLINE$Injurious distance should not stop my way;$NEWLINE$For then, despite of space, I would be brought$NEWLINE$From limits far remote where thou dost stay.$NEWLINE$No matter then although my foot did stand$NEWLINE$Upon the farthest earth removed from thee,$NEWLINE$For nimble thought can jump both sea and land$NEWLINE$As soon as think the place where he would be.$NEWLINE$But ah, thought kills me that I am not thought$NEWLINE$To leap large lengths of miles when thou art gone,$NEWLINE$But that so much of earth and water wrought,$NEWLINE$I must attend time’s leisure with my moan,$NEWLINE$Receiving naughts by elements so slow$NEWLINE$But heavy tears, badges of either’s woe.
paragraphs.translated:
If I were made of thought instead of slow, dull flesh, this wicked distance between us wouldn’t keep me from where I wanted to be. No matter the distance—from the farthest possible regions—I would bring myself to where you are. It wouldn’t matter that my feet were standing on the spot on earth farthest from you: Thought is nimble enough to jump over both sea and land as quickly as it can think about the place it wants to be. But, ah, it’s killing me to think that I’m not made of thought and can’t leap over the many miles when you are gone. Instead my body is made of so much
earth and water that I have to fill the long time without you with my moans. The leaden, deep earth and slow, wet water of which I am made give me nothing but heavy tears.$NEWLINE$earth and water$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: The other two, slight air and purging fire,$NEWLINE$Are both with thee, wherever I abide;$NEWLINE$The first my thought, the other my desire,$NEWLINE$These present absent with swift motion slide.$NEWLINE$For when these quicker elements are gone$NEWLINE$In tender embassy of love to thee,$NEWLINE$My life, being made of four, with two alone$NEWLINE$Sinks down to death, oppressed with melancholy;$NEWLINE$Until life’s composition be recured$NEWLINE$By those swift messengers returned from thee,$NEWLINE$Who ev'n but now come back again, assured$NEWLINE$Of thy fair health, recounting it to me.$NEWLINE$This told, I joy, but then no longer glad,$NEWLINE$I send them back again and straight grow sad.
paragraphs.translated:
The other
two elements, weightless air and purifying fire, both remain with you, wherever I may be. Air is my thoughts, and fire is my desire. The two of them slide back and forth between us swiftly and effortlessly. Normally I am made up of all four elements, but when my air and fire are off on their errand of love to you, I sink into depression and slide toward death, until air and fire return to restore the proper
balance within me. Even now, they have returned from you to tell me that you’re well and in good health. I rejoice to hear this but then immediately grow gloomy from missing you, so I send them back to you and immediately grow sad again.$NEWLINE$two elements$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$balance$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Mine eye and heart are at a mortal war$NEWLINE$How to divide the conquest of thy sight;$NEWLINE$Mine eye my heart thy picture’s sight would bar;$NEWLINE$My heart mine eye the freedom of that right.$NEWLINE$My heart doth plead that thou in him dost lie,$NEWLINE$A closet never pierced with crystal eyes;$NEWLINE$But the defendant doth that plea deny,$NEWLINE$And says in him thy fair appearance lies.$NEWLINE$To 'cide this title is empanellèd$NEWLINE$A quest of thoughts, all tenants to the heart,$NEWLINE$And by their verdict is determinèd$NEWLINE$The clear eye’s moiety and the dear heart’s part:$NEWLINE$As thus—mine eye’s due is thy outward part,$NEWLINE$And my heart’s right, thy inward love of heart.
paragraphs.translated: My eye and my heart have gone to war with each other. They’re fighting over who gets to control your image. My eye wants to bar my heart from the image that it formed, while my heart wants to keep my eye away fromits image. My heart insists that your image lies safely hidden inside of him, protected from eyes, which give everything away. But my eye, the defendant, denies the charges and argues that your beauty resides in him. To decide whose claim is right, I have assembled a jury consisting of my thoughts, all of which owe allegiance to the heart. And they have delivered a verdict to determine which portion of your image belongs to the eyes and which precious portion to the heart. This is what they say: My eyes have the rights to your outward appearance, and my heart has the right to love you and be loved by you.$NEWLINE$its

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Betwixt mine eye and heart a league is took,$NEWLINE$And each doth good turns now unto the other.$NEWLINE$When that mine eye is famished for a look,$NEWLINE$Or heart in love with sighs himself doth smother,$NEWLINE$With my love’s picture then my eye doth feast$NEWLINE$And to the painted banquet bids my heart.$NEWLINE$Another time mine eye is my heart’s guest,$NEWLINE$And in his thoughts of love doth share a part.$NEWLINE$So either by thy picture or my love,$NEWLINE$Thyself away are present still with me;$NEWLINE$For thou no farther than my thoughts canst move,$NEWLINE$And I am still with them, and they with thee;$NEWLINE$Or if they sleep, thy picture in my sight$NEWLINE$Awakes my heart to heart’s and eye’s delight.
paragraphs.translated: My eye and my heart have reached an agreement, and now each does the other favors. When my eye is starving to take a look at you or my heart smothers itself with sighs of love for you, then my eye feasts on a painting of you and invites my heart to join in the banquet and stare at the painting too. On another occasion, my eye is the guest with whom my heart shares some of his thoughts of love. So when you are gone, you’re still present with me, either through your painting or in my love for you: You can’t travel farther than my thoughts, and I’m always with them, and they are always with you. Even if my thoughts go to sleep, your painting will wake up my heart and delight both heart and eyes.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: How careful was I, when I took my way,$NEWLINE$Each trifle under truest bars to thrust,$NEWLINE$That to my use it might unusèd stay$NEWLINE$From hands of falsehood, in sure wards of trust.$NEWLINE$But thou, to whom my jewels trifles are,$NEWLINE$Most worthy comfort, now my greatest grief,$NEWLINE$Thou best of dearest, and mine only care,$NEWLINE$Art left the prey of every vulgar thief.$NEWLINE$Thee have I not locked up in any chest,$NEWLINE$Save where thou art not, though I feel thou art,$NEWLINE$Within the gentle closure of my breast,$NEWLINE$From whence at pleasure thou mayst come and part;$NEWLINE$And even thence thou wilt be stol'n, I fear,$NEWLINE$For truth proves thievish for a prize so dear.
paragraphs.translated: I used to be so careful when I’d travel to secure all my trivial possessions with the most reliable locks available so criminals wouldn’t tamper with them. But you, so much more precious than my jewels and my greatest comfort, have become my greatest sadness and worry, because you’re vulnerable to any common thief. I haven’t locked you up in any chest, other than in my own chest, where my heart is, and you’re not really there, even though I feel that you are. You can come and go from my heart as you please, and I’m afraid you’ll be stolen from there, because even an honest man would turn thief to get such a rich prize.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Against that time (if ever that time come)$NEWLINE$When I shall see thee frown on my defects;$NEWLINE$Whenas thy love hath cast his utmost sum,$NEWLINE$Called to that audit by advised respects;$NEWLINE$Against that time when thou shalt strangely pass,$NEWLINE$And scarcely greet me with that sun, thine eye;$NEWLINE$When love, converted from the thing it was,$NEWLINE$Shall reasons find of settled gravity;$NEWLINE$Against that time do I ensconce me here$NEWLINE$Within the knowledge of mine own desert,$NEWLINE$And this my hand against myself uprear$NEWLINE$To guard the lawful reasons on thy part:$NEWLINE$To leave poor me, thou hast the strength of laws,$NEWLINE$Since why to love I can allege no cause.
paragraphs.translated: In anticipation of the time, if it ever comes, when I will see you frown at my defects; when mature reflection tells you that you’ve come to the end of your love for me; in anticipation of that time when you will pass by me like a stranger, barely even acknowledging me with a glance of your brilliant eye; when your love for me isn’t love anymore and you’re guided only by somber judgment—in anticipation of that time, I’m establishing myself here, knowing how little I really deserve, and I’m giving testimony against myself to defend the justice of your future actions. You have every right to leave poor me—all the laws of reason back you up—since I can’t offer any justification for your loving me.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: How heavy do I journey on the way$NEWLINE$When what I seek (my weary travel’s end)$NEWLINE$Doth teach that ease and that repose to say,$NEWLINE$“Thus far the miles are measured from thy friend.”$NEWLINE$The beast that bears me, tired with my woe,$NEWLINE$Plods dully on to bear that weight in me,$NEWLINE$As if by some instinct the wretch did know$NEWLINE$His rider loved not speed, being made from thee.$NEWLINE$The bloody spur cannot provoke him on$NEWLINE$That sometimes anger thrusts into his hide,$NEWLINE$Which heavily he answers with a groan,$NEWLINE$More sharp to me than spurring to his side;$NEWLINE$For that same groan doth put this in my mind:$NEWLINE$My grief lies onward and my joy behind.
paragraphs.translated: I feel very depressed as I go on my journey, because I know when I get where I’m going I’ll have time and leisure to rest, and when I have that time to rest I’ll have nothing to think about except “I’m this many miles away from my friend.” The horse that carries me, affected by my sadness, plods slowly on, bearing the weight of my emotions, as if by some instinct the poor creature knew that I didn’t want to move quickly away from you. I can’t provoke him to go any faster with the bloody spur that I sometimes thrust into his hide in anger. He only answers me with a groan, which hurts me more than my spur hurts him, because it reminds me that my grief lies ahead of me and all my joy is behind me.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Thus can my love excuse the slow offense$NEWLINE$Of my dull bearer, when from thee I speed:$NEWLINE$From where thou art, why should I haste me thence?$NEWLINE$Till I return, of posting is no need.$NEWLINE$O what excuse will my poor beast then find,$NEWLINE$When swift extremity can seem but slow?$NEWLINE$Then should I spur, though mounted on the wind;$NEWLINE$In wingèd speed no motion shall I know:$NEWLINE$Then can no horse with my desire keep pace;$NEWLINE$Therefore desire, of perfect’st love being made,$NEWLINE$Shall neigh no dull flesh in his fiery race,$NEWLINE$But love, for love, thus shall excuse my jade:$NEWLINE$Since from thee going he went wilful slow,$NEWLINE$Towards thee I’ll run, and give him leave to go.
paragraphs.translated: (Continuing from Sonnet 50) This is how my love for you excuses my horse’s slow plod as I journey away from you: “Why should I hurry away from you?” Until I return, there’s no need to rush. But what excuse will my poor horse have for his slowness then, when even the most extreme swiftness will seem slow to me? On the return journey I’d use my spurs even if the animal rode like the wind. Even if my horse had wings I’d feel like we were standing still. No horse could keep up with my desire then. My desire, made of the most perfect love, will race toward you like a horse made of fire, not neigh like a slow, dull horse made of flesh and blood.
