But, my love, out of love I’ll excuse my horse like this: Since he deliberately went slowly as he was leaving you, I’ll run back to you and forget about the horse altogether.$NEWLINE$(Continuing from Sonnet 50)$NEWLINE$should

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: So am I as the rich whose blessèd key$NEWLINE$Can bring him to his sweet up-lockèd treasure,$NEWLINE$The which he will not every hour survey,$NEWLINE$For blunting the fine point of seldom pleasure.$NEWLINE$Therefore are feasts so solemn and so rare,$NEWLINE$Since seldom coming in the long year set,$NEWLINE$Like stones of worth they thinly placèd are,$NEWLINE$Or captain jewels in the carcanet.$NEWLINE$So is the time that keeps you as my chest,$NEWLINE$Or as the wardrobe which the robe doth hide,$NEWLINE$To make some special instant special blest$NEWLINE$By new unfolding his imprisoned pride.$NEWLINE$Blessèd are you whose worthiness gives scope,$NEWLINE$Being had, to triumph; being lacked, to hope.
paragraphs.translated: I’m like a rich man who has the key to a great treasure chest, but who resists opening it every hour, because he doesn’t want to spoil his pleasure by getting too used to the treasure. That’s why holiday feasts are so infrequent: Spaced out across the year, they’re like precious jewels placed evenly across a crown. In the same way, the time that keeps us apart is my treasure chest, or it’s like a closet that hides a beautiful robe— the closet makes a special occasion even more special when it is opened to reveal its hidden splendor. You are blessed with such great worth that those who are with you feel triumphant, and those who are not with you hope to be.$NEWLINE$my

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: What is your substance, whereof are you made,$NEWLINE$That millions of strange shadows on you tend?$NEWLINE$Since everyone hath every one, one shade,$NEWLINE$And you, but one, can every shadow lend.$NEWLINE$Describe Adonis, and the counterfeit$NEWLINE$Is poorly imitated after you.$NEWLINE$On Helen’s cheek all art of beauty set,$NEWLINE$And you in Grecian tires are painted new.$NEWLINE$Speak of the spring and foison of the year;$NEWLINE$The one doth shadow of your beauty show,$NEWLINE$The other as your bounty doth appear,$NEWLINE$And you in every blessèd shape we know.$NEWLINE$In all external grace you have some part,$NEWLINE$But you like none, none you, for constant heart.
paragraphs.translated:
What is your true essence, what are you made of, that there should be millions of reflections of you? Every person has only one image, but you, though you’re only one person, lend something to everyone else’s image. If an artist tries to depict
Adonis, he’ll wind up creating an inferior imitation of you. If he were to paint
Helen as beautifully as possible, he would again wind up with a picture of you, decked out in Greek costume. Praise the spring and the abundant harvest season—but the spring is only a faint shadow of your beauty, and the fall a faint imitation of your abundance. We recognize you in every blessed sight that we see. You are part of every beautiful thing, but you’re not like any of them—you’re incomparable—in the constancy of your heart.$NEWLINE$Adonis$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$Helen$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: O how much more doth beauty beauteous seem$NEWLINE$By that sweet ornament which truth doth give!$NEWLINE$The rose looks fair, but fairer we it deem$NEWLINE$For that sweet odor which doth in it live.$NEWLINE$The canker-blooms have full as deep a dye$NEWLINE$As the perfumèd tincture of the roses,$NEWLINE$Hang on such thorns, and play as wantonly,$NEWLINE$When summer’s breath their maskèd buds discloses;$NEWLINE$But for their virtue only is their show,$NEWLINE$They live unwooed, and unrespected fade,$NEWLINE$Die to themselves. Sweet roses do not so;$NEWLINE$Of their sweet deaths are sweetest odors made;$NEWLINE$And so of you, beauteous and lovely youth;$NEWLINE$When that shall vade, my verse distills your truth.
paragraphs.translated: Beauty seems so much more beautiful when it comes with honesty and integrity. Roses are beautiful, but we think they’re even more so because of their sweet scent. Wildflowers have as deep a color as fragrant roses; their thorns are the same, and their beauty broadcasts just as loudly when summer opens their buds. But because their only virtue is their looks, no one wants or respects them and they die unnoticed and alone. Sweet roses don’t suffer that fate. When they die, the most fragrant perfumes are made from their corpses. The same is true of you, beautiful youth. When you fade away, my poems will preserve your essence.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Not marble nor the gilded monuments$NEWLINE$Of princes shall outlive this pow'rful rhyme,$NEWLINE$But you shall shine more bright in these conténts$NEWLINE$Than unswept stone, besmeared with sluttish time.$NEWLINE$When wasteful war shall statues overturn,$NEWLINE$And broils root out the work of masonry,$NEWLINE$Nor Mars his sword, nor war’s quick fire, shall burn$NEWLINE$The living record of your memory.$NEWLINE$'Gainst death and all oblivious enmity$NEWLINE$Shall you pace forth; your praise shall still find room$NEWLINE$Even in the eyes of all posterity$NEWLINE$That wear this world out to the ending doom.$NEWLINE$So till the judgment that yourself arise,$NEWLINE$You live in this, and dwell in lovers' eyes.
paragraphs.translated: Neither marble nor the gold-plated monuments of princes will outlive this powerful poetry. You will shine more brightly in these poems than those stones that crumble to dust, blackened by time. When devastating war overturns statues, with its battles uprooting buildings, neither the god of war nor his quick-burning fires shall destroy this record of you. Despite death and ignorant enmity, you shall continue on. All those generations to come, down to the weary end of time, will devote space to praising you. So until Judgment Day, when you are raised up, you will live in this poetry, and in the eyes of lovers who read this.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Sweet love, renew thy force; be it not said$NEWLINE$Thy edge should blunter be than appetite,$NEWLINE$Which but today by feeding is allayed,$NEWLINE$Tomorrow sharpened in his former might.$NEWLINE$So love be thou; although today thou fill$NEWLINE$Thy hungry eyes even till they wink with fullness,$NEWLINE$Tomorrow see again, and do not kill$NEWLINE$The spirit of love with a perpetual dullness.$NEWLINE$Let this sad int'rim like the ocean be$NEWLINE$Which parts the shore, where two contracted new$NEWLINE$Come daily to the banks, that when they see$NEWLINE$Return of love, more blest may be the view;$NEWLINE$Else call it winter, which being full of care,$NEWLINE$Makes summer’s welcome, thrice more wished, more rare.
paragraphs.translated:
Sweet
love, be as strong as you used to be. Don’t let people say that love is less keen and persistent than lust, which may be satiated today but then comes back tomorrow just as strong and sharp as ever. That’s how you should be, love. Although today you see so much of your love that you want to shut your eyes, look again tomorrow: Do not kill your affection by making yourself perpetually dull and lethargic. Let this sad period of separation be like an ocean that lies between two opposite shores; two newly betrothed lovers come every day to the opposite banks hoping to see each other, and when they do, the sight feels especially blessed. Or call this time winter, which, being full of misery, makes us wish for summer three times more than if it didn’t feel so rare.$NEWLINE$love$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Being your slave, what should I do but tend$NEWLINE$Upon the hours and times of your desire?$NEWLINE$I have no precious time at all to spend,$NEWLINE$Nor services to do, till you require.$NEWLINE$Nor dare I chide the world without end hour$NEWLINE$Whilst I, my sovereign, watch the clock for you,$NEWLINE$Nor think the bitterness of absence sour$NEWLINE$When you have bid your servant once adieu.$NEWLINE$Nor dare I question with my jealous thought$NEWLINE$Where you may be, or your affairs suppose,$NEWLINE$But, like a sad slave, stay and think of nought$NEWLINE$Save, where you are, how happy you make those.$NEWLINE$So true a fool is love that in your will,$NEWLINE$Though you do anything, he thinks no ill.
paragraphs.translated: Since I’m your slave, what else should I do but wait on the hours, and for the times when you’ll want me? I don’t have any valuable time to spend, or any services to do, until you need me. Nor do I dare complain about how agonizingly long the hours are while I watch the clock for you, my king, or how bitter your absence is after you’ve said goodbye to your servant. Nor do I dare ask jealous questions about where you might be, or speculate about your affairs, but like a sad slave I sit still and think about nothing except how happy you’re making whomever you’re with. Love makes a person such a faithful fool that no matter what you do to satisfy your desires, he doesn’t think you’ve done anything wrong.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: That god forbid, that made me first your slave,$NEWLINE$I should in thought control your times of pleasure,$NEWLINE$Or at your hand th' account of hours to crave,$NEWLINE$Being your vassal bound to stay your leisure.$NEWLINE$O let me suffer, being at your beck,$NEWLINE$Th' imprisoned absence of your liberty;$NEWLINE$And patience tame to sufferance bide each check,$NEWLINE$Without accusing you of injury.$NEWLINE$Be where you list, your charter is so strong$NEWLINE$That you yourself may privilege your time$NEWLINE$To what you will; to you it doth belong$NEWLINE$Yourself to pardon of self-doing crime.$NEWLINE$I am to wait, though waiting so be hell,$NEWLINE$Not blame your pleasure, be it ill or well.
paragraphs.translated: (Continuing from Sonnet 57) Whatever god decided to make me your slave, may he never allow me to so much as think about having any control over when you see me, or asking you to account for how you’ve been passing the hours. I’m your slave, after all, and forced to wait until you have time for me. Oh, while I wait for your summons, let me suffer patiently the prison of this lengthy absence from you as you do whatever you want. And let me control my impatience and quietly endure each disappointment without accusing you of hurting me. Go wherever you want—you’re so privileged that you may decide to do whatever you like. You have the right to pardon yourself for any crime you commit. And I have to wait, even if it feels like hell, and not blame you for following your desire, whether it’s for good or bad.$NEWLINE$(Continuing from Sonnet 57)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: If there be nothing new, but that which is$NEWLINE$Hath been before, how are our brains beguiled,$NEWLINE$Which, lab'ring for invention, bear amiss$NEWLINE$The second burthen of a former child!$NEWLINE$O that recórd could with a backward look,$NEWLINE$Ev'n of five hundred courses of the sun,$NEWLINE$Show me your image in some ántique book,$NEWLINE$Since mind at first in character was done,$NEWLINE$That I might see what the old world could say$NEWLINE$To this composèd wonder of your frame;$NEWLINE$Whether we are mended, or where better they,$NEWLINE$Or whether revolution be the same.$NEWLINE$O sure I am the wits of former days$NEWLINE$To subjects worse have giv'n admiring praise.
paragraphs.translated: If it’s true that there’s nothing new and everything that now exists existed in the past, then we are really fooling ourselves when we struggle to write something new, winding up, after much exhausting, painful labor, with a tired imitation of an imitation! If only I could look back into the records, even as far as five hundred years ago, and find a description of you in some old book, written when people were just beginning to put their thoughts in writing, so I could see what the old world would say about your amazingly beautiful body. Then I could see whether we’ve gotten better at writing or worse, or whether things have stayed the same as the world revolves. Oh, I’m sure the witty writers of the past have devoted praise and admiration to worse subjects than you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Like as the waves make towards the pebbled shore,$NEWLINE$So do our minutes hasten to their end,$NEWLINE$Each changing place with that which goes before,$NEWLINE$In sequent toil all forwards do contend.$NEWLINE$Nativity, once in the main of light,$NEWLINE$Crawls to maturity, wherewith being crowned,$NEWLINE$Crooked eclipses 'gainst his glory fight,$NEWLINE$And time that gave doth now his gift confound.$NEWLINE$Time doth transfix the flourish set on youth$NEWLINE$And delves the parallels in beauty’s brow;$NEWLINE$Feeds on the rarities of nature’s truth,$NEWLINE$And nothing stands but for his scythe to mow.$NEWLINE$And yet to times in hope my verse shall stand,$NEWLINE$Praising thy worth, despite his cruel hand.
paragraphs.translated: As the waves move toward the pebbled shore, so do the minutes we have to live hasten toward their end, each moment changing place with the one before, striving to move forward with successive efforts. Everything that has been born, though it once swam in that broad ocean of light that exists before birth, crawls its way up the shores of maturity, where it faces cruel obstacles to its glory. Time, which gives everything, now destroys its own gift. Time pierces the beauty of youth, drawing wrinkles in beauty’s forehead. Time devours the choicest specimens of nature; nothing exists that it won’t mow down with its scythe. And yet my verses will last into the future, praising your worth despite Time’s cruel hand.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Is it thy will thy image should keep open$NEWLINE$My heavy eyelids to the weary night?$NEWLINE$Dost thou desire my slumbers should be broken,$NEWLINE$While shadows like to thee do mock my sight?$NEWLINE$Is it thy spirit that thou send’st from thee$NEWLINE$So far from home into my deeds to pry,$NEWLINE$To find out shames and idle hours in me,$NEWLINE$The scope and tenor of thy jealousy?$NEWLINE$O no; thy love, though much, is not so great.$NEWLINE$It is my love that keeps mine eye awake,$NEWLINE$Mine own true love that doth my rest defeat,$NEWLINE$To play the watchman ever for thy sake.$NEWLINE$For thee watch I whilst thou dost wake elsewhére,$NEWLINE$From me far off, with others all too near.
paragraphs.translated: Was it your intention that I should stay awake all night thinking about you? Do you want my sleep to be interrupted while I’m tantalized by mental images of you? Are you sending your spirit far from its home to pry into my dealings, to find out the shameful things I’ve been up to in idle hours? Are you jealous? Oh, no: Though you love me a great deal, you don’t love me that much. It’s my love for you that’s keeping me awake. My own true love keeps me from sleeping—staying up worrying about you. I stay up for you, while you are awake somewhere else: far away from me, but all too close to certain other people.$NEWLINE$my$NEWLINE$you

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Sin of self-love possesseth all mine eye$NEWLINE$And all my soul, and all my every part;$NEWLINE$And for this sin there is no remedy,$NEWLINE$It is so grounded inward in my heart.$NEWLINE$Methinks no face so gracious is as mine,$NEWLINE$No shape so true, no truth of such account;$NEWLINE$And for myself mine own worth do define,$NEWLINE$As I all other in all worths surmount.$NEWLINE$But when my glass shows me myself indeed,$NEWLINE$Beated and chopped with tanned antiquity,$NEWLINE$Mine own self-love quite contrary I read;$NEWLINE$Self so self-loving were iniquity.$NEWLINE$'Tis thee, myself, that for myself I praise,$NEWLINE$Painting my age with beauty of thy days.
paragraphs.translated: The sin of self-love controls everything I see, and my entire soul, and every part of me. There’s no way to get rid of this sin, it’s so deeply rooted in my heart. I think that no one’s face is as gracious as mine, no body so evenly proportioned, no one’s integrity of such high worth. I calculate my value such that I surpass everybody else in everything. But when my mirror shows me how I really look, beaten and cracked by age and the sun, I come to an opposite conclusion: For myself to love myself so much would be a sinful error. It’s you I’m praising when I praise myself, ornamenting my old age with the beauty of your youth.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Against my love shall be as I am now,$NEWLINE$With time’s injurious hand crushed and o'erworn;$NEWLINE$When hours have drained his blood and filled his brow$NEWLINE$With lines and wrinkles; when his youthful morn$NEWLINE$Hath traveled on to age’s steepy night,$NEWLINE$And all those beauties whereof now he’s king$NEWLINE$Are vanishing or vanished out of sight,$NEWLINE$Stealing away the treasure of his spring;$NEWLINE$For such a time do I now fortify$NEWLINE$Against confounding age’s cruel knife,$NEWLINE$That he shall never cut from memory$NEWLINE$My sweet love’s beauty, though my lover’s life.$NEWLINE$His beauty shall in these black lines be seen,$NEWLINE$And they shall live, and he in them still green.
paragraphs.translated: In anticipation of the time when my love shall be as I am now, crushed and worn out by time’s damaging hand; when time has sapped his vigor and filled his forehead with wrinkles; when his youthful morning has moved on to the difficult night of old age, and all of those forms of beauty that he now possesses are disappearing, or already gone, robbing him of the treasures of his youth—in anticipation of that time, I’m now defending myself against the cruel knife of time, ensuring that he never cuts from my memory the beauty of my sweet love, even if he takes my lover’s life. My lover’s beauty will remain visible in these black lines of poetry, and these lines shall survive, and he will live on in them, still young.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: When I have seen by time’s fell hand defaced$NEWLINE$The rich proud cost of outworn buried age;$NEWLINE$When sometime lofty towers I see down-razed,$NEWLINE$And brass eternal slave to mortal rage;$NEWLINE$When I have seen the hungry ocean gain$NEWLINE$Advantage on the kingdom of the shore,$NEWLINE$And the firm soil win of the watery main,$NEWLINE$Increasing store with loss, and loss with store;$NEWLINE$When I have seen such interchange of state,$NEWLINE$Or state itself confounded to decay,$NEWLINE$Ruin hath taught me thus to ruminate,$NEWLINE$That time will come and take my love away.$NEWLINE$This thought is as a death, which cannot choose$NEWLINE$But weep to have that which it fears to lose.
paragraphs.translated: Now that I have seen time’s terrible hand deface the costly and splendid monuments of buried men from ages past, and once-lofty towers torn down; now that I have seen even hard brass subject to perpetual destruction by human beings; now that I have seen the hungry ocean swallow up the land and firm land seize territory from the ocean, so that each one’s loss is the other’s gain; now that I have seen that all things constantly change into something else or fall into decay—all this destruction has taught me to think: The time will come in which time will take my love from me. This thought feels like death, and makes me weep over what I have that I’m afraid of losing.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Since brass, nor stone, nor earth, nor boundless sea,$NEWLINE$But sad mortality o'ersways their power,$NEWLINE$How with this rage shall beauty hold a plea,$NEWLINE$Whose action is no stronger than a flower?$NEWLINE$O how shall summer’s honey breath hold out$NEWLINE$Against the wrackful siege of batt'ring days,$NEWLINE$When rocks impregnable are not so stout,$NEWLINE$Nor gates of steel so strong but time decays?$NEWLINE$O fearful meditation! Where, alack,$NEWLINE$Shall time’s best jewel from time’s chest lie hid?$NEWLINE$Or what strong hand can hold his swift foot back?$NEWLINE$Or who his spoil or beauty can forbid?$NEWLINE$O none, unless this miracle have might,$NEWLINE$That in black ink my love may still shine bright.
paragraphs.translated: Since neither brass nor stone nor earth nor the limitless ocean is strong enough to resist the sad force of mortality, how can beauty possibly resist death’s rage when beauty is no stronger than a flower? How could your beauty, which is as fragile as the sweet breath of summer, hold out against the destructive assaults of time when neither invulnerable rocks nor gates of steel are strong enough to resist its decaying power? What a frightening thing to think about! Alas, where can I put your beauty, time’s most precious creation, to hide it from time itself? Whose hand is strong enough to slow time down? Who will forbid its destruction of your beauty? Oh, no one, unless this miracle proves effective: that in the black ink of my poetry, the one I love may still shine bright.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Tired with all these, for restful death I cry,$NEWLINE$As to behold desert a beggar born,$NEWLINE$And needy nothing trimmed in jollity,$NEWLINE$And purest faith unhappily forsworn,$NEWLINE$And gilded honor shamefully misplaced,$NEWLINE$And maiden virtue rudely strumpeted,$NEWLINE$And right perfection wrongfully disgraced,$NEWLINE$And strength by limping sway disablèd,$NEWLINE$And art made tongue-tied by authority,$NEWLINE$And folly, doctor-like, controlling skill,$NEWLINE$And simple truth miscalled simplicity,$NEWLINE$And captive good attending captain ill.$NEWLINE$Tired with all these, from these would I be gone,$NEWLINE$Save that to die, I leave my love alone.
paragraphs.translated: Because I’m tired of all of these things, I cry out for restful death: deserving people destined to be beggars, and worthless people dressed up in fancy clothes, and sacred vows broken, and rewards and honors shamefully bestowed on the wrong people, and chaste women turned into whores, and people perfectly in the right disgraced with slander, and the strong disabled by authorities who are weak, and artists silenced by authority, and fools controlling the wise like a doctor does the sick, and simple truth mistaken for simplemindedness, and good enslaved by evil. I’m tired of all these things and would like to escape them, except that if I die I’ll be leaving the person I love all alone.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Ah, wherefore with infection should he live,$NEWLINE$And with his presence grace impiety,$NEWLINE$That sin by him advantage should achieve$NEWLINE$And lace itself with his society?$NEWLINE$Why should false painting imitate his cheek,$NEWLINE$And steal dead seeing of his living hue?$NEWLINE$Why should poor beauty indirectly seek$NEWLINE$Roses of shadow, since his rose is true?$NEWLINE$Why should he live, now nature bankrupt is,$NEWLINE$Beggared of blood to blush through lively veins?$NEWLINE$For she hath no exchequer now but his,$NEWLINE$And, proud of many, lives upon his gains.$NEWLINE$O him she stores, to show what wealth she had$NEWLINE$In days long since, before these last so bad.
paragraphs.translated: (Continuing from Sonnet 66) Ah, why should the man I love have to live in the midst of all this corruption, gracing sinners with his presence so they can take advantage of their association with him? Why should portrait painters and makeup artists be allowed to imitate his face, making lifeless copies of his vibrant beauty? Why should those less beautiful than he imitate roses by false means, when he is a true rose? And why should he live, now that Nature has degenerated so much that she can hardly infuse anyone with vigor and beauty? Because she has no fund of beauty now except him and, having so many children to provide for, needs to borrow from his store. Oh, Nature keeps him alive in order to show the wealth of beauty she had long ago, before these recent bad days came.$NEWLINE$(Continuing from Sonnet 66)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Thus is his cheek the map of days outworn,$NEWLINE$When beauty lived and died as flow'rs do now,$NEWLINE$Before these bastard signs of fair were born,$NEWLINE$Or durst inhabit on a living brow;$NEWLINE$Before the golden tresses of the dead,$NEWLINE$The right of sepulchers, were shorn away,$NEWLINE$To live a second life on second head;$NEWLINE$Ere beauty’s dead fleece made another gay.$NEWLINE$In him those holy ántique hours are seen,$NEWLINE$Without all ornament, itself and true,$NEWLINE$Making no summer of another’s green,$NEWLINE$Robbing no old to dress his beauty new;$NEWLINE$And him as for a map doth nature store,$NEWLINE$To show false art what beauty was of yore.
paragraphs.translated: (Continuing from Sonnet 67) So his face is the incarnation of how things were in the old days, when beautiful people lived and died as commonly as flowers—before these illegitimate signs of beauty were created, or anyone dared to put them on a living human being. That was before the golden locks of corpses, which belong in graves, were cut off and made to live a second life on a second person’s head. It was before the hair of a beautiful corpse served to make another person happy. You can see the old-fashioned youthful beauty of his face: no wig to ornament it, the real thing in all its honesty, not borrowing someone else’s youth nor stealing from the old to look new again. Nature preserves him as a map, to show cosmetics what beauty used to be.$NEWLINE$(Continuing from Sonnet 67)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Those parts of thee that the world’s eye doth view$NEWLINE$Want nothing that the thought of hearts can mend.$NEWLINE$All tongues, the voice of souls, give thee that due,$NEWLINE$Utt'ring bare truth, ev'n so as foes commend.$NEWLINE$Thy outward thus with outward praise is crowned;$NEWLINE$But those same tongues that give thee so thine own$NEWLINE$In other accents do this praise confound$NEWLINE$By seeing farther than the eye hath shown.$NEWLINE$They look into the beauty of thy mind,$NEWLINE$And that in guess they measure by thy deeds;$NEWLINE$Then, churls, their thoughts (although their eyes were kind)$NEWLINE$To thy fair flower add the rank smell of weeds;$NEWLINE$But why thy odor matcheth not thy show,$NEWLINE$The soil is this, that thou dost common grow.
paragraphs.translated: Those parts of you that are visible to the world lack nothing, and no one could imagine improving them. Everybody admits this unreservedly, though they’re only saying what’s obviously true—what even your enemies praise you for. Thus, your outside is rewarded with public praise. But the same people who give you the praise your beauty deserves take quite another tack once they’ve looked beyond the surface. These people examine the beauty of your mind and character, and they guess at what’s in there by observing your actions. Then, though they judged your appearance kindly, their harsh thoughts tell them that although you appear beautiful you smell corrupt. So, if you don’t smell as good as you look, this is the reason: You’re hanging out with lowlifes.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: That thou art blamed shall not be thy defect,$NEWLINE$For slander’s mark was ever yet the fair;$NEWLINE$The ornament of beauty is suspéct,$NEWLINE$A crow that flies in heaven’s sweetest air.$NEWLINE$So thou be good, slander doth but approve$NEWLINE$Thy worth the greater, being wooed of time;$NEWLINE$For canker vice the sweetest buds doth love,$NEWLINE$And thou present’st a pure unstainèd prime.$NEWLINE$Thou hast passed by the ambush of young days,$NEWLINE$Either not assailed, or victor being charged;$NEWLINE$Yet this thy praise cannot be so thy praise,$NEWLINE$To tie up envy evermore enlarged.$NEWLINE$If some suspéct of ill masked not thy show,$NEWLINE$Then thou alone kingdoms of hearts shouldst owe.
paragraphs.translated: The fact that people say bad things about you won’t be held against you, because beautiful people have always been the target of slander. Beautiful people are always the objects of suspicion, a black crow darkening heaven. As long as you’re good, you’re a target of temptation; slander just proves how worthy you are. For vice, like a worm, loves to devour the sweetest buds the most, which makes you—in your prime, pure and unstained—a perfect target. You’ve escaped the traps that usually endanger young men, because either no one tempted you or you resisted the temptation. However, this praise I’ve given you won’t inflate your reputation so much that it keeps envious people from talking, because they always will. If your beauty weren’t masked by at least some suspicion of evil, you’d be the most beloved person in the world.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: No longer mourn for me when I am dead$NEWLINE$Than you shall hear the surly sullen bell$NEWLINE$Give warning to the world that I am fled$NEWLINE$From this vile world with vildest worms to dwell:$NEWLINE$Nay, if you read this line, remember not$NEWLINE$The hand that writ it, for I love you so$NEWLINE$That I in your sweet thoughts would be forgot,$NEWLINE$If thinking on me then should make you woe.$NEWLINE$O if, I say, you look upon this verse$NEWLINE$When I perhaps compounded am with clay,$NEWLINE$Do not so much as my poor name rehearse,$NEWLINE$But let your love even with my life decay,$NEWLINE$Lest the wise world should look into your moan$NEWLINE$And mock you with me after I am gone.
paragraphs.translated: When I am dead, mourn for me only as long as you hear the funeral bell telling the world that I’ve left this vile world to go live with the vile worms. No, if you read this line, don’t remember who wrote it, because I love you so much that I’d rather you forgot me than thought about me and became sad. I’m telling you, if you look at this poem when I’m, say, dissolved in the earth, don’t so much as utter my name but let your love die with me. Otherwise, the world, in all its wisdom, will investigate why you’re sad and use me to mock you, now that I am gone.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: O lest the world should task you to recite$NEWLINE$What merit lived in me that you should love$NEWLINE$After my death, dear love, forget me quite,$NEWLINE$For you in me can nothing worthy prove;$NEWLINE$Unless you would devise some virtuous lie,$NEWLINE$To do more for me than mine own desert,$NEWLINE$And hang more praise upon deceasèd I$NEWLINE$Than niggard truth would willingly impart.$NEWLINE$O lest your true love may seem false in this,$NEWLINE$That you for love speak well of me untrue,$NEWLINE$My name be buried where my body is,$NEWLINE$And live no more to shame nor me nor you.$NEWLINE$For I am shamed by that which I bring forth,$NEWLINE$And so should you, to love things nothing worth.
paragraphs.translated: (Continuing from Sonnet 71) Oh, in case the world challenges you to recite what merit I possessed that would justify your loving me, forget about me entirely after I die, dear love. For you won’t find anything worthy to say about me unless you make up some generous lie, which makes me sound better than I deserve, and attach more praise to my dead self than accords with the stingy truth. Oh, to prevent your true love from becoming false, as it will, in part, if you make false statements out of love for me, let my name be buried with my corpse and no longer bring shame to you or me. For I’m ashamed of what I produce, and you should be, too, to love such worthless things.$NEWLINE$(Continuing from Sonnet 71)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: That time of year thou mayst in me behold$NEWLINE$When yellow leaves, or none, or few, do hang$NEWLINE$Upon those boughs which shake against the cold,$NEWLINE$Bare ruined choirs, where late the sweet birds sang.$NEWLINE$In me thou seest the twilight of such day$NEWLINE$As after sunset fadeth in the west,$NEWLINE$Which by and by black night doth take away,$NEWLINE$Death’s second self, that seals up all in rest.$NEWLINE$In me thou seest the glowing of such fire$NEWLINE$That on the ashes of his youth doth lie,$NEWLINE$As the deathbed whereon it must expire$NEWLINE$Consumed with that which it was nourished by.$NEWLINE$This thou perceiv’st, which makes thy love more strong,$NEWLINE$To love that well which thou must leave ere long.
paragraphs.translated: When you look at me, you can see an image of those times of year when the leaves are yellow or have fallen, or when the trees have no leaves at all and the bare branches where the sweet birds recently sang shiver in anticipation of the cold. In me you can see the twilight that remains after the sunset fades in the west, which by and by is replaced by black night, the twin of death, which closes up everyone in eternal rest. In me you can see the remains of a fire still glowing atop the ashes of its early stages, as if it lay on its own deathbed, on which it has to burn out, consuming what used to fuel it. You see all these things, and they make your love stronger, because you love even more what you know you’ll lose before long.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: But be contented when that fell arrest$NEWLINE$Without all bail shall carry me away;$NEWLINE$My life hath in this line some interest,$NEWLINE$Which for memorial still with thee shall stay.$NEWLINE$When thou reviewest this, thou dost review$NEWLINE$The very part was consecrate to thee.$NEWLINE$The earth can have but earth, which is his due;$NEWLINE$My spirit is thine, the better part of me.$NEWLINE$So then thou hast but lost the dregs of life,$NEWLINE$The prey of worms, my body being dead,$NEWLINE$The coward conquest of a wretch’s knife,$NEWLINE$Too base of thee to be rememb’red.$NEWLINE$The worth of that is that which it contains,$NEWLINE$And that is this, and this with thee remains.
paragraphs.translated: (Continuing from Sonnet 73) But don’t be upset when death arrives to carry me off where no one can release me. My life will continue to some extent in these lines, which you’ll always have to remember me by. When you reread this, you’ll be seeing again the precise part of me that was dedicated to you. The earth can only have the earthly part of me, which is what belongs to it. My spirit, the better part of me, is yours. So when I’m dead you’ll have only my body—the dregs of my life, the part that worms eat, the only part of me that cowardly, wretched death could kill, the part that’s too worthless for you to remember. What gives my body its worth is the spirit it contains, and that spirit is this poem, and this poem will remain with you.$NEWLINE$(Continuing from Sonnet 73)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: So are you to my thoughts as food to life,$NEWLINE$Or as sweet seasoned show'rs are to the ground;$NEWLINE$And for the peace of you I hold such strife$NEWLINE$As ’twixt a miser and his wealth is found;$NEWLINE$Now proud as an enjoyer, and anon$NEWLINE$Doubting the filching age will steal his treasure;$NEWLINE$Now counting best to be with you alone,$NEWLINE$Then bettered that the world may see my pleasure;$NEWLINE$Sometime all full with feasting on your sight$NEWLINE$And by and by clean starvèd for a look;$NEWLINE$Possessing or pursuing no delight,$NEWLINE$Save what is had or must from you be took.$NEWLINE$Thus do I pine and surfeit day by day,$NEWLINE$Or gluttoning on all, or all away.
paragraphs.translated: I need you the way living things need food or the grass needs rain, and to attain the peace that only you can give me, I fight with myself the way a miser struggles with his wealth. One moment he enjoys his wealth proudly, and the next he’s worried that someone from these thieving times will steal his treasure. One moment I think it’s best to be alone with you, but then I think it would be better if the rest of the world could see my pleasure. At times I feel oversatisfied from looking at you excessively, but a little later I’m starving to get a look at you. I can’t experience or pursue any enjoyment except what you can give me or I can take from you. That’s why I suffer and feel hungry day after day, because I either get too much of you or none at all.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Why is my verse so barren of new pride,$NEWLINE$So far from variation or quick change?$NEWLINE$Why with the time do I not glance aside$NEWLINE$To new-found methods and to compounds strange?$NEWLINE$Why write I still all one, ever the same,$NEWLINE$And keep invention in a noted weed,$NEWLINE$That every word doth almost tell my name,$NEWLINE$Showing their birth, and where they did proceed?$NEWLINE$O know, sweet love, I always write of you,$NEWLINE$And you and love are still my argument.$NEWLINE$So all my best is dressing old words new,$NEWLINE$Spending again what is already spent:$NEWLINE$For as the sun is daily new and old,$NEWLINE$So is my love still telling what is told.
paragraphs.translated: Why is my poetry so lacking in new ornaments, so determined in avoiding variation and change? Why don’t I, like everyone else these days, take a look at the new literary styles and weird combinations of other writers? Why do I always write the same thing, always the same, and always in the same distinctive style, so that almost every word I write tells you who wrote it, where it was born, and where it comes from? Oh, you should know, sweet love, I always write about you, and you and love are continually my subjects. So the best I can do is find new words to say the same thing, spending again what I’ve already spent: Just as the sun is new and old every day, my love for you keeps making me tell what I’ve already told.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Thy glass will show thee how thy beauties wear,$NEWLINE$Thy dial how thy precious minutes waste;$NEWLINE$The vacant leaves thy mind’s impr'nt will bear,$NEWLINE$And of this book this learning mayst thou taste:$NEWLINE$The wrinkles which thy glass will truly show$NEWLINE$Of mouthèd graves will give thee memory;$NEWLINE$Thou by thy dial’s shady stealth mayst know$NEWLINE$Time’s thievish progress to eternity.$NEWLINE$Look what thy memory cannot contain,$NEWLINE$Commit to these waste blanks, and thou shalt find$NEWLINE$Those children nursed, delivered from thy brain,$NEWLINE$To take a new acquaintance of thy mind.$NEWLINE$These offices, so oft as thou wilt look,$NEWLINE$Shall profit thee and much enrich thy book.
paragraphs.translated: Your mirror will show you how your beauty is wearing away; your clock how your precious minutes are slipping away; the pages of this blank notebook will record your thoughts; and you may learn the following things from those thoughts: The wrinkles that your mirror will show you will remind you of open graves. By the hands of your clock, you’ll learn how time keeps stealing away to eternity. Write down whatever you can’t remember on these blank pages, and later, when you encounter those thoughts again, the children of your brain, they’ll have grown up, nourished by your continued reflection. They’ll be like a new acquaintance. Doing these things often—looking in the mirror and at the clock, and writing in the book—will benefit you and greatly enrich your book.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: So oft have I invoked thee for my muse,$NEWLINE$And found such fair assistance in my verse,$NEWLINE$As every alien pen hath got my use,$NEWLINE$And under thee their poesy disperse.$NEWLINE$Thine eyes, that taught the dumb on high to sing,$NEWLINE$And heavy ignorance aloft to fly,$NEWLINE$Have added feathers to the learnèd’s wing$NEWLINE$And given grace a double majesty.$NEWLINE$Yet be most proud of that which I compile,$NEWLINE$Whose influence is thine and born of thee.$NEWLINE$In others' works thou dost but mend the style,$NEWLINE$And arts with thy sweet graces gracèd be;$NEWLINE$But thou art all my art, and dost advance$NEWLINE$As high as learning my rude ignorance.
paragraphs.translated: I have cited you as my source of inspiration so often, and you’ve helped my poetry so much, that every other writer has adopted my habit of addressing poems to you, and now they all write their poetry in your name. Your beautiful eyes are such a source of inspiration that they’ve helped the mute sing high notes, raised the ignorant to new heights of intelligence, helped the educated soar even higher, and enhanced the gracefulness of the graceful. Yet your greatest pride should be in my accomplishment, because it’s done under your influence and inspired by you. With other writers, you only improve their style, adding an extra sheen to the skill they already have. But without you I have no skill at all; you lift up my utter ignorance so that I am well-educated.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Whilst I alone did call upon thy aid,$NEWLINE$My verse alone had all thy gentle grace,$NEWLINE$But now my gracious numbers are decayed,$NEWLINE$And my sick muse doth give another place.$NEWLINE$I grant, sweet love, thy lovely argument$NEWLINE$Deserves the travail of a worthier pen,$NEWLINE$Yet what of thee thy poet doth invent$NEWLINE$He robs thee of and pays it thee again.$NEWLINE$He lends thee virtue, and he stole that word$NEWLINE$From thy behavior; beauty doth he give$NEWLINE$And found it in thy cheek; he can afford$NEWLINE$No praise to thee but what in thee doth live.$NEWLINE$Then thank him not for that which he doth say,$NEWLINE$Since what he owes thee thou thyself dost pay.
paragraphs.translated: When I was the only writer who looked to you for inspiration, only my poetry received all of the benefits of your noble grace. But now the poems I write under your inspiration have gotten worse, and I’m forced to make room for someone else. I admit, my sweet love, that such a lovely subject as you deserves to have a better writer working for you. But whatever your new poet says about you, he’s only stealing the ideas from you and giving them back to you. He says you’re virtuous, but he only learned that word from watching your behavior. He says you’re beautiful, but he only found out about beauty from your face. He has no praise to give you except for what he finds in you already. So don’t thank him for what he says about you, since you’re paying for everything he gives you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: O how I faint when I of you do write,$NEWLINE$Knowing a better spirit doth use your name,$NEWLINE$And in the praise thereof spends all his might,$NEWLINE$To make me tongue-tied speaking of your fame.$NEWLINE$But since your worth, wide as the ocean is,$NEWLINE$The humble as the proudest sail doth bear,$NEWLINE$My saucy bark, inferior far to his,$NEWLINE$On your broad main doth willfully appear.$NEWLINE$Your shallowest help will hold me up afloat,$NEWLINE$Whilst he upon your soundless deep doth ride;$NEWLINE$Or, being wracked, I am a worthless boat,$NEWLINE$He of tall building and of goodly pride.$NEWLINE$Then, if he thrive and I be cast away,$NEWLINE$The worst was this: my love was my decay.
paragraphs.translated: I get very discouraged when I write about you, knowing that a superior writer is writing about you too. He uses all of his powers of praise to make me tongue-tied when I write about your glory. But since your worth is as big as the ocean, able to support the smallest boat as well as the biggest ship, my impudent little boat, which is far inferior to his, stubbornly makes an appearance on your waters. Even at your shallowest, you keep me afloat, while he sails out over your measureless depths. And if I wind up being wrecked, I’m only a worthless little vessel, whereas he’s a tall ship—something to be proud of. So if he does well and I find myself shipwrecked and discarded, the worst I can say is this: I was destroyed because of my love for you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Or I shall live, your epitaph to make,$NEWLINE$Or you survive, when I in earth am rotten,$NEWLINE$From hence your memory death cannot take,$NEWLINE$Although in me each part will be forgotten.$NEWLINE$Your name from hence immortal life shall have,$NEWLINE$Though I, once gone, to all the world must die.$NEWLINE$The earth can yield me but a common grave,$NEWLINE$When you entombèd in men’s eyes shall lie.$NEWLINE$Your monument shall be my gentle verse,$NEWLINE$Which eyes not yet created shall o'er-read,$NEWLINE$And tongues to be your being shall rehearse$NEWLINE$When all the breathers of this world are dead.$NEWLINE$You still shall live—such virtue hath my pen—$NEWLINE$Where breath most breathes, ev'n in the mouths of men.
paragraphs.translated: Either I will live to write your epitaph after you die, or you will survive me when I’m rotting in the grave. Death cannot take away your memory, but it will cause everything to do with me to be forgotten. Your name will live eternally, but once I’m gone, I’ll be dead to the world. I’ll only be granted an ordinary grave, but your tomb will be where everyone can see it. Your monument will be these tender poems of mine, which future generations will read and talk about, when everyone who’s now living is dead. My pen has such power that you’ll not only stay alive, you’ll live where the essence of life resides: in the breath and voices of men.$NEWLINE$me

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: I grant thou wert not married to my muse,$NEWLINE$And therefore mayst without attaint o'erlook$NEWLINE$The dedicated words which writers use$NEWLINE$Of their fair subject, blessing every book.$NEWLINE$Thou art as fair in knowledge as in hue,$NEWLINE$Finding thy worth a limit past my praise,$NEWLINE$And therefore art enforced to seek anew$NEWLINE$Some fresher stamp of the time-bett'ring days.$NEWLINE$And do so, love; yet when they have devised$NEWLINE$What strainèd touches rhetoric can lend,$NEWLINE$Thou, truly fair, wert truly sympathized$NEWLINE$In true plain words by thy true-telling friend.$NEWLINE$And their gross painting might be better used$NEWLINE$Where cheeks need blood—in thee it is abused.
paragraphs.translated: I admit that you weren’t married to my poetry, so you’re not doing anything wrong if you read what other writers say about you in the books they dedicate to you—you, the beautiful subject that blesses their books. You are as knowledgeable as you are beautiful, and you see that I’m incapable of praising you sufficiently, so you’re forced to look again for some newer, fresher writer in these days of literary improvements. Go ahead and do so, my love. Yet while these writers have invented whatever elaborate stylistic devices they can borrow from rhetoric, you would be more truthfully represented, since you’re truly beautiful, by the true, plain words of your truth-telling friend. And the overblown praise of these other writers might be more appropriately applied to people who need to be beautified. For you, such rhetorical excess is misused.$NEWLINE$need

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: I never saw that you did painting need,$NEWLINE$And therefore to your fair no painting set.$NEWLINE$I found, or thought I found, you did exceed$NEWLINE$The barren tender of a poet’s debt.$NEWLINE$And therefore have I slept in your report,$NEWLINE$That you yourself, being extant, well might show$NEWLINE$How far a modern quill doth come too short,$NEWLINE$Speaking of worth, what worth in you doth grow.$NEWLINE$This silence for my sin you did impute,$NEWLINE$Which shall be most my glory, being dumb.$NEWLINE$For I impair not beauty, being mute,$NEWLINE$When others would give life, and bring a tomb.$NEWLINE$There lives more life in one of your fair eyes$NEWLINE$Than both your poets can in praise devise.
paragraphs.translated: It never seemed to me that you needed to be praised, so I never described your beauty with profuse or elaborate rhetoric. I could see (or I thought I could see) that you were better than any praise a poet could give you. Therefore, I haven’t exerted myself to describe you, so that you yourself, since you’re still alive, could show everybody how much more worthy you are than my commonplace writing style can describe. You decided that this silence on my part was a fault, but I’m particularly proud of my muteness. By remaining silent, at least I don’t damage your beauty, whereas other writers try to bring you to life in their writing, and kill you instead. You possess more life in one of your beautiful eyes than all of your poets could invent by praising you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Who is it that says most, which can say more$NEWLINE$Than this rich praise, that you alone are you—$NEWLINE$In whose conf'ne immurèd is the store$NEWLINE$Which should example where your equal grew?$NEWLINE$Lean penury within that pen doth dwell$NEWLINE$That to his subject lends not some small glory.$NEWLINE$But he that writes of you, if he can tell$NEWLINE$That you are you, so dignifies his story.$NEWLINE$Let him but copy what in you is writ,$NEWLINE$Not making worse what nature made so clear,$NEWLINE$And such a counterpart shall fame his wit,$NEWLINE$Making his style admired everywhere.$NEWLINE$You to your beauteous blessings add a curse,$NEWLINE$Being fond on praise, which makes your praises worse.
paragraphs.translated: Which writer says the most about you? Which of them can say anything more to praise you than that only you are you, and that all beauty is stored in you, so that there’s nothing to compare you to but yourself? Only a very poor writer is unable to improve the subject he’s writing about at least a little, but whoever writes about you will have given his writing dignity simply by reporting that you are you. If that writer simply describes you accurately, managing not to mess up what nature made so perfectly, he’ll have created such an image that his writing skills will become famous, his style admired everywhere. For all of the beauty you’re blessed with, you curse yourself by loving to hear yourself praised so much, because then people write worse praise trying to flatter you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: My tongue-tied muse in manners holds her still,$NEWLINE$While comments of your praise, richly compiled,$NEWLINE$Reserve their character with golden quill$NEWLINE$And precious phrase by all the muses filed.$NEWLINE$I think good thoughts, whilst other write good words,$NEWLINE$And like unlettered clerk still cry “Amen”$NEWLINE$To every hymn that able spirit affords,$NEWLINE$In polished form of well-refinèd pen.$NEWLINE$Hearing you praised, I say “'Tis so, ’tis true,”$NEWLINE$And to the most of praise add something more;$NEWLINE$But that is in my thought, whose love to you,$NEWLINE$Though words come hindmost, holds his rank before.$NEWLINE$Then others for the breath of words respect,$NEWLINE$Me for my dumb thoughts, speaking in effect.
paragraphs.translated:
My mute poetry politely remains silent, while commentaries praising you pile up, capturing the essence of your character in golden words and precious phrases inspired by all the muses. I think good thoughts about you while other people write good words, and like an illiterate parish clerk I continually cry
“amen” to every poem of praise that capable poets produce about you in their polished and refined style. When I hear you praised, I say, “That’s right, that’s true,” and add a little something to their utmost praise of you. What I add is only in my own mind, but in my own mind I know I love you the most, though I speak the least. So respect others for the words of praise they offer you, but respect me for my silent thoughts, which express themselves only in actions.$NEWLINE$“amen”$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Was it the proud full sail of his great verse,$NEWLINE$Bound for the prize of all too precious you,$NEWLINE$That did my ripe thoughts in my brain inhearse,$NEWLINE$Making their tomb the womb wherein they grew?$NEWLINE$Was it his spirit, by spirits taught to write$NEWLINE$Above a mortal pitch, that struck me dead?$NEWLINE$No, neither he, nor his compeers by night$NEWLINE$Giving him aid, my verse astonishèd.$NEWLINE$He, nor that affable familiar ghost$NEWLINE$Which nightly gulls him with intelligence,$NEWLINE$As victors of my silence cannot boast.$NEWLINE$I was not sick of any fear from thence;$NEWLINE$But when your countenance filled up his line,$NEWLINE$Then lacked I matter, that enfeebled mine.
paragraphs.translated:
Was it the ambitious and impressive poem that my rival wrote for you that discouraged me from writing my own poem, killing my thoughts before I could put them into words? Was it his creative power, aided by the
spirits of all the dead authors he’s read so that he writes better than any mortal should, that stunned me into silence? No, it was neither him nor those friends of his who visit him at night and help him, who silenced me with amazement. Neither he nor that friendly little ghost that tricks him with false information each night can boast that they’re responsible for my silence. I wasn’t sick because of any fear of them. But when you looked favorably on his writing and thus made it even better, then I suddenly had nothing to say, and you made my writing feeble.$NEWLINE$spirits$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Farewell, thou art too dear for my possessing,$NEWLINE$And like enough thou know’st thy estimate.$NEWLINE$The charter of thy worth gives thee releasing;$NEWLINE$My bonds in thee are all determinate.$NEWLINE$For how do I hold thee but by thy granting,$NEWLINE$And for that riches where is my deserving?$NEWLINE$The cause of this fair gift in me is wanting,$NEWLINE$And so my patent back again is swerving.$NEWLINE$Thyself thou gav’st, thy own worth then not knowing,$NEWLINE$Or me, to whom thou gav’st it, else mistaking;$NEWLINE$So thy great gift, upon misprision growing,$NEWLINE$Comes home again, on better judgment making.$NEWLINE$Thus have I had thee as a dream doth flatter:$NEWLINE$In sleep a king, but waking no such matter.
paragraphs.translated: Goodbye; you’re too valuable for me to hold onto, and you probably know exactly what you’re worth. Your high value gives you the right to leave me; you have severed the ties that bind me to you. For what hold do I have over you except the hold that you choose to give me, and how do I deserve such a treasure? There’s nothing in me to justify such a beautiful gift, so my right to possess you is reverting back to you. When you gave yourself to me, you didn’t know your own worth, or else you were mistaken about me, the person you gave yourself to. So the great gift you gave me, being based on a false estimate, goes back to you now that you’re able to make a better judgment. Thus, the time in which I had you was like a flattering dream; while I was asleep, I thought I was a king, but when I woke up, I found that was not the case.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: When thou shalt be disposed to set me light$NEWLINE$And place my merit in the eye of scorn,$NEWLINE$Upon thy side against myself I’ll fight,$NEWLINE$And prove thee virtuous, though thou art forsworn.$NEWLINE$With mine own weakness being best acquainted,$NEWLINE$Upon thy part I can set down a story$NEWLINE$Of faults concealed, wherein I am attainted,$NEWLINE$That thou in losing me shalt win much glory.$NEWLINE$And I by this will be a gainer too,$NEWLINE$For bending all my loving thoughts on thee,$NEWLINE$The injuries that to myself I do,$NEWLINE$Doing thee vantage, double vantage me.$NEWLINE$Such is my love, to thee I so belong,$NEWLINE$That for thy right myself will bear all wrong.
paragraphs.translated: When you feel inclined to think little of me and make other people scorn me, I’ll take your side and argue against myself, demonstrating that you’re virtuous even while you’re lying about me. Since I know my own weaknesses better than anyone, I can tell a story about my hidden faults (in which I reveal myself as morally tainted) that will have people thinking better of you for not being with me anymore. And I, too, will gain by turning all my loving thoughts to you: Whatever injuries I do to myself will help you, which will help me doubly. I love you so much—belong to you so totally—that to get you everything you’re entitled to, I will take every wrong upon myself.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Say that thou didst forsake me for some fault,$NEWLINE$And I will comment upon that offense.$NEWLINE$Speak of my lameness, and I straight will halt,$NEWLINE$Against thy reasons making no defense.$NEWLINE$Thou canst not, love, disgrace me half so ill,$NEWLINE$To set a form upon desired change,$NEWLINE$As I’ll myself disgrace, knowing thy will;$NEWLINE$I will acquaintance strangle and look strange,$NEWLINE$Be absent from thy walks, and in my tongue$NEWLINE$Thy sweet belovèd name no more shall dwell,$NEWLINE$Lest I, too much profane, should do it wrong$NEWLINE$And haply of our old acquaintance tell.$NEWLINE$For thee against myself I’ll vow debate,$NEWLINE$For I must ne'er love him whom thou dost hate.
paragraphs.translated: (Continuing from Sonnet 88) If you tell people you left me because of some fault of mine, I will expand upon whatever you say I did wrong. Say I’m lame, and I’ll start limping immediately, without trying to defend myself against your accusations. My love, in finding a reason to justify leaving me, you can’t disgrace me half as badly as I’ll disgrace myself, as soon as I know what you want. I’ll pretend I don’t know you and act like a stranger. I won’t go where I might run into you. And I won’t mention your beloved name anymore in case I’d dirty it by reminding people that we used to be acquainted. For your sake, I’ll vow to be my own enemy, because I must not love someone whom you hate.$NEWLINE$(Continuing from Sonnet 88)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Then hate me when thou wilt, if ever, now,$NEWLINE$Now while the world is bent my deeds to cross;$NEWLINE$Join with the spite of fortune, make me bow,$NEWLINE$And do not drop in for an after-loss:$NEWLINE$Ah, do not, when my heart hath ’scaped this sorrow,$NEWLINE$Come in the rearward of a conquered woe.$NEWLINE$Give not a windy night a rainy morrow,$NEWLINE$To linger out a purposed overthrow.$NEWLINE$If thou wilt leave me, do not leave me last,$NEWLINE$When other petty griefs have done their spite$NEWLINE$But in the onset come; so shall I taste$NEWLINE$At first the very worst of fortune’s might;$NEWLINE$And other strains of woe, which now seem woe,$NEWLINE$Compared with loss of thee will not seem so.
paragraphs.translated: (Continuing from Sonnet 89) So hate me when you want to, but if you’re ever going to, do it now, now while the world is determined to frustrate everything I try to do. Add to my misfortune, make me collapse under it, don’t hit me with this later, after I’ve already endured so many other blows. Ah, do not let me think I’ve avoided the sorrow of losing you, then come and reject me—right after I’ve been defeated by another grief. Don’t turn my windy night into a rainy tomorrow, prolonging the defeat you intend to give me. If you’re going to leave me, don’t wait until the end, after other little sorrows have done their damage. Leave me at the beginning, so I experience the worst misfortune first. Then other hurtful things, which seem painful now, won’t seem so, compared with losing you.$NEWLINE$(Continuing from Sonnet 89)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Some glory in their birth, some in their skill,$NEWLINE$Some in their wealth, some in their body’s force,$NEWLINE$Some in their garments, though new-fangled ill,$NEWLINE$Some in their hawks and hounds, some in their horse;$NEWLINE$And every humor hath his adjunct pleasure,$NEWLINE$Wherein it finds a joy above the rest.$NEWLINE$But these particulars are not my measure;$NEWLINE$All these I better in one general best.$NEWLINE$Thy love is better than high birth to me,$NEWLINE$Richer than wealth, prouder than garments' cost,$NEWLINE$Of more delight than hawks or horses be;$NEWLINE$And having thee, of all men’s pride I boast;$NEWLINE$Wretched in this alone, that thou mayst take$NEWLINE$All this away, and me most wretched make.
paragraphs.translated: Some people are proud of the social status they’ve inherited; some people of their abilities; some of their wealth; some of how strong they are; some of their clothes, though the clothes are trendy and weird; some are proud of their hawks and hounds; some of their horses; and every individual temperament has its particular pleasure, something the person enjoys above everything else. But I don’t measure happiness by any of these things. There’s something else that’s better than them all. To me, your love is better than high social status, more valuable than wealth, more worth being proud of than expensive clothes, and more enjoyable than hawks or horses. And having you, I have something better than what other men are proud of—except I’m wretched in this one respect: You can take all this away from me and make me completely wretched.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: But do thy worst to steal thyself away,$NEWLINE$For term of life thou art assurèd mine,$NEWLINE$And life no longer than thy love will stay,$NEWLINE$For it depends upon that love of thine.$NEWLINE$Then need I not to fear the worst of wrongs,$NEWLINE$When in the least of them my life hath end.$NEWLINE$I see a better state to me belongs$NEWLINE$Than that which on thy humor doth depend.$NEWLINE$Thou canst not vex me with inconstant mind,$NEWLINE$Since that my life on thy revolt doth lie.$NEWLINE$O what a happy title do I find,$NEWLINE$Happy to have thy love, happy to die!$NEWLINE$But what’s so blessèd-fair that fears no blot?$NEWLINE$Thou mayst be false, and yet I know it not.
paragraphs.translated: (Continuing from Sonnet 91) But go ahead and leave me—do your best to hurt me. I’m sure to have you as long as I’m alive, because I will only be alive as long as you love me: My life depends on your love. Now I don’t have to worry about all the terrible things you might do to hurt me; as soon as you hurt me even a little, I’ll die. I realize now that I’m in a better position than I would be if I were dependent on your affections. You can’t worry me with the idea that you’re fickle, since my life would be over as soon as you changed your mind about me. Oh, what a happy position I’m in: I’m happy to have your love, but also happy to die! But what situation is so perfectly blessed that it breeds no worries? You might be unfaithful to me without my knowing it.$NEWLINE$(Continuing from Sonnet 91)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: So shall I live, supposing thou art true,$NEWLINE$Like a deceived husband; so love’s face$NEWLINE$May still seem love to me, though altered new:$NEWLINE$Thy looks with me, thy heart in other place.$NEWLINE$For there can live no hatred in thine eye,$NEWLINE$Therefore in that I cannot know thy change.$NEWLINE$In many’s looks, the false heart’s history$NEWLINE$Is writ in moods and frowns and wrinkles strange,$NEWLINE$But heav'n in thy creation did decree$NEWLINE$That in thy face sweet love should ever dwell;$NEWLINE$Whate'er thy thoughts or thy heart’s workings be,$NEWLINE$Thy looks should nothing thence but sweetness tell.$NEWLINE$How like Eve’s apple doth thy beauty grow,$NEWLINE$If thy sweet virtue answer not thy show.
paragraphs.translated: (Continuing from Sonnet 92) In that case, I’ll live like a deceived husband, assuming you’re faithful. Then your face will still show that you love me, even though you don’t—your looks will stay the same, but your heart will be somewhere else. As your face could never have a hateful expression, I couldn’t ever know a change of heart from looking at it. Many people express their unfaithfulness in their faces—in moody looks and frowns and strange wrinkles. But when heaven created you, it decided that your face would always express sweet love. Whatever your thoughts or desires, your looks never express anything but sweetness. In fact, your beauty becomes much like Eve’s apple when you’re not as sweet and virtuous as you look.$NEWLINE$(Continuing from Sonnet 92)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: They that have pow'r to hurt, and will do none,$NEWLINE$That do not do the thing they most do show,$NEWLINE$Who moving others are themselves as stone,$NEWLINE$Unmovèd, cold, and to temptation slow,$NEWLINE$They rightly do inherit heaven’s graces,$NEWLINE$And husband nature’s riches from expense.$NEWLINE$They are the lords and owners of their faces;$NEWLINE$Others but stewards of their excellence.$NEWLINE$The summer’s flow'r is to the summer sweet,$NEWLINE$Though to itself it only live and die.$NEWLINE$But if that flow'r with base infection meet,$NEWLINE$The basest weed outbraves his dignity.$NEWLINE$For sweetest things turn sourest by their deeds;$NEWLINE$Lilies that fester smell far worse than weeds.
paragraphs.translated: Those whose beauty gives them the power to hurt others, but who refuse to; those who look very sexy but won’t have sex; who attract other people but are themselves like stones—cold, unemotional, and difficult to tempt—those are the ones who will rightly inherit heaven’s blessings and keep nature’s treasures from being wasted. Those who have self-control truly own their beauty; the rest are only administering their beauty for others' use. The summer flower seems sweet to us in summer, though the flower itself may feel that it’s only living and dying. But if that flower lets itself be infected by a parasite, the lowest weed will be better, for the sweetest things have the capacity to turn the sourest by acting wrongly. Lilies that rot smell a lot worse than weeds.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: How sweet and lovely dost thou make the shame$NEWLINE$Which, like a canker in the fragrant rose,$NEWLINE$Doth spot the beauty of thy budding name!$NEWLINE$O in what sweets dost thou thy sins enclose!$NEWLINE$That tongue that tells the story of thy days,$NEWLINE$Making lascivious comments on thy sport,$NEWLINE$Cannot dispraise but in a kind of praise;$NEWLINE$Naming thy name blesses an ill report.$NEWLINE$O what a mansion have those vices got$NEWLINE$Which for their habitation chose out thee,$NEWLINE$Where beauty’s veil doth cover every blot,$NEWLINE$And all things turns to fair that eyes can see!$NEWLINE$Take heed, dear heart, of this large privilege;$NEWLINE$The hardest knife ill used doth lose his edge.
paragraphs.translated: You make the flaw that’s ruining your reputation (like a worm infecting a rosebud) look so sweet and lovely. Oh, you cover up your sins with such a sweet exterior! The person who accuses you of wild lust somehow manages to turn his criticisms into praise: Your name makes bad actions look good. Oh, the vices you have inside you live in a beautiful house. Your beauty serves as a veil that makes every bad thing you do seem good! But be careful, dear heart, with this great privilege that your beauty gives you. If you abuse it, it will stop working, like a knife that loses its edge from misuse.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Some say thy fault is youth, some wantonness,$NEWLINE$Some say thy grace is youth and gentle sport;$NEWLINE$Both grace and faults are loved of more and less;$NEWLINE$Thou mak’st faults graces that to thee resort.$NEWLINE$As on the finger of a thronèd queen$NEWLINE$The basest jewel will be well esteemed,$NEWLINE$So are those errors that in thee are seen$NEWLINE$To truths translated, and for true things deemed.$NEWLINE$How many lambs might the stern wolf betray,$NEWLINE$If like a lamb he could his looks translate;$NEWLINE$How many gazers mightst thou lead away,$NEWLINE$If thou wouldst use the strength of all thy state!$NEWLINE$But do not so. I love thee in such sort,$NEWLINE$As thou being mine, mine is thy good report.
paragraphs.translated: Some say your fault is your youth, others that the problem is your lustfulness. Some say your youth and playfulness are charming. Both important and unimportant people love your charms and your faults too. You turn your faults into sources of charm. Just as a worthless jewel is regarded as valuable when a queen is wearing it, so the sins that people see you commit are turned into good characteristics and regarded as good. How many lambs could the grim wolf trick if he could make himself look like a lamb? How many people might you lead astray if you seduced them with the full force of your beauty and social position? But don’t do that. I love you so much (since you are mine) that your reputation extends to me as well.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: How like a winter hath my absence been$NEWLINE$From thee, the pleasure of the fleeting year!$NEWLINE$What freezings have I felt, what dark days seen!$NEWLINE$What old December’s bareness everywhere!$NEWLINE$And yet this time removed was summer’s time,$NEWLINE$The teeming autumn big with rich increase,$NEWLINE$Bearing the wanton burthen of the prime,$NEWLINE$Like widowed wombs after their lords' decease.$NEWLINE$Yet this abundant issue seemed to me$NEWLINE$But hope of orphans, and unfathered fruit.$NEWLINE$For summer and his pleasures wait on thee,$NEWLINE$And thou away, the very birds are mute.$NEWLINE$Or if they sing, ’tis with so dull a cheer$NEWLINE$That leaves look pale, dreading the winter’s near.
paragraphs.translated:
My separation from you has felt just like winter, since you’re what makes the year pleasurable! I’ve felt very cold, and the days have seemed very dark, and everything has been as barren as in December! And yet the time we’ve been apart was actually summer, then fall, the harvest-time when nature gives birth to crops planted in the
springlike a woman giving birth after her husband has died. And these abundant fruits of nature seemed like hopeless orphans to me, because summer and summer’s pleasures all depend on you, and, with you away, even the birds are silent. Or if they sing, they do it so dismally that the leaves grow pale with fear, dreading the fact that winter’s almost here.$NEWLINE$spring$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: From you have I been absent in the spring,$NEWLINE$When proud-pied April, dressed in all his trim,$NEWLINE$Hath put a spirit of youth in everything,$NEWLINE$That heavy Saturn laughed and leapt with him.$NEWLINE$Yet nor the lays of birds, nor the sweet smell$NEWLINE$Of different flow'rs in odor and in hue,$NEWLINE$Could make me any summer’s story tell,$NEWLINE$Or from their proud lap pluck them where they grew.$NEWLINE$Nor did I wonder at the lily’s white,$NEWLINE$Nor praise the deep vermilion in the rose;$NEWLINE$They were but sweet, but figures of delight,$NEWLINE$Drawn after you, you pattern of all those.$NEWLINE$Yet seemed it winter still, and, you away,$NEWLINE$As with your shadow I with these did play.
paragraphs.translated: I was away from you during the spring, when splendid April in all its finery made everything feel so young that even Saturn, the god of old age and gloominess, laughed and leaped along with it. But neither the songs of birds nor the sweet smell of all the various flowers could make me feel like it was summer or inspire me to go flower picking. I wasn’t amazed by how white the lily was, nor did I praise the deep red of the roses. They were only sweet, only pictures of delight, drawn in imitation of you, the archetype of spring. It seemed like it was still winter and, with you away, I played with these flowers as if I were playing with your reflection.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: The forward violet thus did I chide:$NEWLINE$Sweet thief, whence didst thou steal thy sweet that smells,$NEWLINE$If not from my love’s breath? The purple pride$NEWLINE$Which on thy soft cheek for complexion dwells$NEWLINE$In my love’s veins thou hast too grossly dyed.$NEWLINE$The lily I condemnèd for thy hand,$NEWLINE$And buds of marjoram had stol'n thy hair;$NEWLINE$The roses fearfully on thorns did stand,$NEWLINE$One blushing shame, another white despair;$NEWLINE$A third, nor red nor white, had stol'n of both,$NEWLINE$And to his robb'ry had annexed thy breath;$NEWLINE$But for his theft, in pride of all his growth$NEWLINE$A vengeful canker ate him up to death.$NEWLINE$More flow'rs I noted, yet I none could see$NEWLINE$But sweet or color it had stol'n from thee.
paragraphs.translated: (Continuing from Sonnet 98) This is how I scolded the presumptuous violet: “Sweet thief, where did you steal your sweet smell from if not from my beloved’s breath? You obviously got that purple color you’re so proud of by dying yourself in his blood.” I condemned the lily for stealing its whiteness from your hand and the marjoram buds for stealing your curly hair. The roses stood by anxiously, the red one blushing in shame, the white one pale with despair, knowing they were guilty of stealing your colors too. A third rose, neither red nor white, had stolen both red and white from your complexion, and added to his robbery the smell of your breath. But as punishment for his theft, a vengeful worm destroyed the rose just at its proudest growth. I noticed other flowers, and I couldn’t see any that hadn’t stolen its sweetness or color from you.$NEWLINE$(Continuing from Sonnet 98)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Where art thou, Muse, that thou forget’st so long$NEWLINE$To speak of that which gives thee all thy might?$NEWLINE$Spend’st thou thy fury on some worthless song,$NEWLINE$Dark'ning thy pow'r to lend base subjects light?$NEWLINE$Return, forgetful Muse, and straight redeem$NEWLINE$In gentle numbers time so idly spent;$NEWLINE$Sing to the ear that doth thy lays esteem,$NEWLINE$And gives thy pen both skill and argument.$NEWLINE$Rise, resty Muse; my love’s sweet face survey,$NEWLINE$If time have any wrinkle graven there;$NEWLINE$If any, be a satire to decay,$NEWLINE$And make time’s spoils despisèd everywhere.$NEWLINE$Give my love fame faster than time wastes life;$NEWLINE$So thou prevent’st his scythe and crookèd knife.
paragraphs.translated: Where have you been, Muse, that you have forgotten for so long to inspire me to write about the person who gives you all your power? Are you using up your inspiration on some worthless poem, eclipsing your true powers by making unworthy topics seem brighter? Return, forgetful Muse, and make up for the time you’ve wasted by inspiring me to write some gentle verses. Inspire poems addressed to my beloved, the person who actually likes your songs, and who gives you both poetic skill and a topic to write about. Get up, sleepy Muse: Examine my beloved’s sweet face to see if time has engraved any wrinkles on it. If there are any, then satirize aging and make everybody despise time’s destructive powers. Make my beloved famous faster than time can destroy his life; prevent time’s knife from cutting my beloved down.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: O truant Muse, what shall be thy amends$NEWLINE$For thy neglect of truth in beauty dyed?$NEWLINE$Both truth and beauty on my love depends;$NEWLINE$So dost thou too, and therein dignified.$NEWLINE$Make answer, Muse: wilt thou not haply say$NEWLINE$Truth needs no color, with his color fixed,$NEWLINE$Beauty no pencil, beauty’s truth to lay;$NEWLINE$But best is best if never intermixed?$NEWLINE$Because he needs no praise, wilt thou be dumb?$NEWLINE$Excuse not silence so, for ’t lies in thee$NEWLINE$To make him much outlive a gilded tomb,$NEWLINE$And to be praised of ages yet to be.$NEWLINE$Then do thy office, Muse. I teach thee how$NEWLINE$To make him seem long hence as he shows now.
paragraphs.translated: (Continuing from Sonnet 100) Oh truant Muse, how are you going to make amends for neglecting my beloved, the embodiment of truth bound up with beauty? Both truth and beauty depend upon my beloved. You depend on, and are dignified by, him too. Answer me, Muse; perhaps you’ll say, “Truth doesn’t need to be embellished when it’s already attached to beauty. Beauty doesn’t need to be poetically described in order for its truth to be apparent. Whatever is best is best when it’s not mixed with anything else.” But just because my beloved needs no praise, will you be silent? You can’t excuse this silence, as you have the ability to make him live longer than a golden tomb and win the praise of future ages. Then do your job, Muse. I’ll teach you how to make him look in the distant future like he does now.$NEWLINE$(Continuing from Sonnet 100)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: My love is strengthened, though more weak in seeming;$NEWLINE$I love not less, though less the show appear.$NEWLINE$That love is merchandised whose rich esteeming$NEWLINE$The owner’s tongue doth publish everywhere.$NEWLINE$Our love was new, and then but in the spring,$NEWLINE$When I was wont to greet it with my lays,$NEWLINE$As Philomel in summer’s front doth sing,$NEWLINE$And stops his pipe in growth of riper days.$NEWLINE$Not that the summer is less pleasant now$NEWLINE$Than when her mournful hymns did hush the night,$NEWLINE$But that wild music burthens every bough,$NEWLINE$And sweets grown common lose their dear delight.$NEWLINE$Therefore, like her, I sometime hold my tongue,$NEWLINE$Because I would not dull you with my song.
