paragraphs.translated: My love is stronger, though it seems weaker. I don’t love less, but I show my love less. When a person broadcasts how he loves and how richly he esteems the person he loves, he turns his love into a commodity. Our love was still new when I used to write poems about it, just as the nightingale sings at the beginning of summer, then stops singing as the summer progresses. It’s not that summer is less pleasant now than the nights when the nightingale sang. It’s just that every tree branch is filled with songbirds, and when things are common they’re less delightful. Therefore, like the nightingale, sometimes I keep silent because I don’t want to bore you with my song.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Alack, what poverty my muse brings forth,$NEWLINE$That having such a scope to show her pride,$NEWLINE$The argument all bare is of more worth$NEWLINE$Than when it hath my added praise beside!$NEWLINE$O blame me not if I no more can write!$NEWLINE$Look in your glass, and there appears a face$NEWLINE$That overgoes my blunt invention quite,$NEWLINE$Dulling my lines and doing me disgrace.$NEWLINE$Were it not sinful then, striving to mend,$NEWLINE$To mar the subject that before was well?$NEWLINE$For to no other pass my verses tend$NEWLINE$Than of your graces and your gifts to tell;$NEWLINE$And more, much more than in my verse can sit$NEWLINE$Your own glass shows you, when you look in it.
paragraphs.translated: Alas, I’m a poor poet, since even with such a great subject to write about (you), the subject is worth more by itself than with my praise added to it. Don’t blame me if I can’t write anymore! Look in the mirror, and you’ll see a face that quite overwhelms my limited poetic skills, making my lines stupid and thereby disgracing me. It would be a sin, wouldn’t it, if in trying to improve my poetry, I messed up their subject, which was perfectly fine before? For the only things I write about are your charms and your wonderful qualities, and your own mirror will show you far, far more of these than I can possibly fit into my poetry.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: To me, fair friend, you never can be old,$NEWLINE$For as you were when first your eye I eyed,$NEWLINE$Such seems your beauty still. Three winters cold$NEWLINE$Have from the forests shook three summers' pride;$NEWLINE$Three beauteous springs to yellow autumn turned$NEWLINE$In process of the seasons have I seen;$NEWLINE$Three April pérfumes in three hot Junes burned,$NEWLINE$Since first I saw you fresh, which yet are green.$NEWLINE$Ah yet doth beauty, like a dial hand,$NEWLINE$Steal from his figure, and no pace perceived;$NEWLINE$So your sweet hue, which methinks still doth stand,$NEWLINE$Hath motion, and mine eye may be deceived.$NEWLINE$For fear of which, hear this, thou age unbred:$NEWLINE$Ere you were born was beauty’s summer dead.
paragraphs.translated: You’ll never be old to me, beautiful friend, for your beauty seems just the same as it was when I first saw your lovely eyes. Since then, three cold winters have stripped the leaves off three proud summers; three beautiful springs have turned to three yellow autumns, all in the course of the seasons. Three Aprils, full of perfumed flowers, have all burned up into three hot Junes since the first day I saw you in your freshness—and you’re still fresh and green. Ah, but beauty, like the hand of a clock, creeps away from the person it’s attached to so slowly no one can see it. In the same way, your sweet beauty, which seems to be standing still, is actually changing, and my eye may be deceived. In case it is, hear this, future generations: Before you were born, the greatest example of beauty was already dead.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Let not my love be called idolatry,$NEWLINE$Nor my belovèd as an idol show,$NEWLINE$Since all alike my songs and praises be$NEWLINE$To one, of one, still such, and ever so.$NEWLINE$Kind is my love today, tomorrow kind,$NEWLINE$Still constant in a wondrous excellence;$NEWLINE$Therefore my verse to constancy confined,$NEWLINE$One thing expressing, leaves out difference.$NEWLINE$Fair, kind, and true is all my argument,$NEWLINE$Fair, kind, and true, varying to other words;$NEWLINE$And in this change is my invention spent—$NEWLINE$Three themes in one, which wondrous scope affords.$NEWLINE$Fair, kind, and true have often lived alone,$NEWLINE$Which three, till now, never kept seat in one.
paragraphs.translated:
Let no one call my love
idolatryor say that I treat my beloved as an idol, since all of my poems and praises have been addressed to one person, are about one person, and always will be. My love is kind today, will be kind tomorrow, always constant in wondrous excellence. Therefore, since my poetry is confined to a subject that’s always the same, it always expresses the same thing, never including anything different. The subject of my poems is the beautiful, kind, and faithful. I write about the beautiful, kind, and faithful in various ways, and this is the task that I expend all of my creativity on—three themes rolled up in one person, which offers an amazing scope for poetic invention. Beauty, kindness, and fidelity have often been divided into different people, but the three of them were never together in one person until now.$NEWLINE$idolatry$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: When in the chronicle of wasted time$NEWLINE$I see descriptions of the fairest wights$NEWLINE$And beauty making beautiful old rhyme$NEWLINE$In praise of ladies dead and lovely knights,$NEWLINE$Then in the blazon of sweet beauty’s best,$NEWLINE$Of hand, of foot, of lip, of eye, of brow,$NEWLINE$I see their ántique pen would have expressed$NEWLINE$Ev'n such a beauty as you master now.$NEWLINE$So all their praises are but prophecies$NEWLINE$Of this our time, all you prefiguring,$NEWLINE$And for they looked but with divining eyes,$NEWLINE$They had not skill enough your worth to sing.$NEWLINE$For we which now behold these present days,$NEWLINE$Have eyes to wonder, but lack tongues to praise.
paragraphs.translated: When in accounts of historic times I come upon descriptions of very beautiful people and read the beautiful poems inspired by them, in praise of ladies now dead and lovely knights; when I see the poems catalog their beauty—their hands, feet, lips, eyes, foreheads—I realize that these ancient writers were trying to describe the same kind of beauty that you possess now. So all the praises of these writers are actually prophecies of our time; all of them prefigure you. If the writers hadn’t been divinely inspired with this gift of prophecy, they wouldn’t have had the skill to describe your worth. Those of us who live now may be able to see your beauty firsthand and be amazed by it, but we lack the poetic skill to describe it.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Not mine own fears, nor the prophetic soul$NEWLINE$Of the wide world dreaming on things to come,$NEWLINE$Can yet the lease of my true love control,$NEWLINE$Supposed as forfeit to a cónfined doom.$NEWLINE$The mortal moon hath her eclipse endured$NEWLINE$And the sad augurs mock their own preságe;$NEWLINE$Incertainties now crown themselves assured,$NEWLINE$And peace proclaims olives of endless age.$NEWLINE$Now with the drops of this most balmy time$NEWLINE$My love looks fresh, and death to me subscribes,$NEWLINE$Since spite of him I’ll live in this poor rhyme,$NEWLINE$While he insults o'er dull and speechless tribes.$NEWLINE$And thou in this shalt find thy monument,$NEWLINE$When tyrants' crests and tombs of brass are spent.
paragraphs.translated:
Neither my own fears nor the speculations of the rest of the world about the future can continue to keep me from possessing my beloved, who everybody thought was doomed to remain in prison. The
moon, which was always mortal, has finally been eclipsed, and the gloomy fortune-tellers now laugh at their own predictions. Things that once seemed doubtful have become certainties, and peace has come to stay. Now, with the blessings of these times, my beloved looks fresh again and death itself submits to me, since in spite of death I’ll live on in this poor poem while death only exults over the stupid and illiterate peoples that he’s overcome. And you will find this poem to be your monument when tyrants reach the end of their reigns and tombs of brass fall into decay.$NEWLINE$moon$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: What’s in the brain that ink may character$NEWLINE$Which hath not figured to thee my true spirit?$NEWLINE$What’s new to speak, what now to register,$NEWLINE$That may express my love or thy dear merit?$NEWLINE$Nothing, sweet boy; but yet, like prayers divine,$NEWLINE$I must each day say o'er the very same,$NEWLINE$Counting no old thing old, thou mine, I thine,$NEWLINE$Ev'n as when first I hallowed thy fair name.$NEWLINE$So that eternal love in love’s fresh case$NEWLINE$Weighs not the dust and injury of age,$NEWLINE$Nor gives to necessary wrinkles place,$NEWLINE$But makes antiquity for aye his page,$NEWLINE$Finding the first conceit of love there bred$NEWLINE$Where time and outward form would show it dead.
paragraphs.translated: What could I possibly write that I haven’t written already to show you how constant and faithful my soul is? What else is there to say, what new thing can I invent, that would express either my love or your value? There’s nothing, sweet boy. And yet, just as with prayers to God, I have to keep saying the same thing over and over again each day, without thinking that these old praises are old. You’re mine, I’m yours, just like when I first honored your name in writing. My love for you, which is everlasting, doesn’t care about the effects of age, nor does it acknowledge your wrinkles, but always inspires me to describe my feelings as if they were still young. I see in you the original source of my love for you, even though your age and appearance would suggest that the reason for that love is dead.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: O never say that I was false of heart,$NEWLINE$Though absence seemed my flame to qualify.$NEWLINE$As easy might I from myself depart$NEWLINE$As from my soul, which in thy breast doth lie.$NEWLINE$That is my home of love; if I have ranged,$NEWLINE$Like him that travels I return again,$NEWLINE$Just to the time, not with the time exchanged,$NEWLINE$So that myself bring water for my stain.$NEWLINE$Never believe, though in my nature reigned$NEWLINE$All frailties that besiege all kinds of blood,$NEWLINE$That it could so preposterously be stained$NEWLINE$To leave for nothing all thy sum of good.$NEWLINE$For nothing this wide universe I call,$NEWLINE$Save thou, my rose; in it thou art my all.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, never say that I was unfaithful to you in my heart, even though my absence from you suggested that my love had weakened. I can’t separate myself from my feelings for you anymore than I can separate myself from myself. You are my home, and if I strayed away from you, like a traveler I have returned again, right at the appointed time, with my feelings unchanged, so I’m making up for my misdeed. Even though I have the same weaknesses in my nature as everyone made of flesh and blood, don’t ever believe that I could be so morally compromised as to leave someone as good as you in exchange for something worthless. The entire universe except for you, my love, means nothing to me. You’re everything to me.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Alas ’tis true, I have gone here and there,$NEWLINE$And made myself a motley to the view,$NEWLINE$Gored mine own thoughts, sold cheap what is most dear,$NEWLINE$Made old offenses of affections new.$NEWLINE$Most true it is that I have looked on truth$NEWLINE$Askance and strangely; but by all above,$NEWLINE$These blenches gave my heart another youth,$NEWLINE$And worse essays proved thee my best of love.$NEWLINE$Now all is done, save what shall have no end;$NEWLINE$Mine appetite I never more will grind$NEWLINE$On newer proof, to try an older friend,$NEWLINE$A god in love, to whom I am confined.$NEWLINE$Then give me welcome, next my heav'n the best,$NEWLINE$Ev'n to thy pure and most most loving breast.
paragraphs.translated: Alas, it’s true, I have gone here and there, and made myself look foolish, and allowed my thoughts to be divided, and acted as if the most valuable thing were worthless, and used my new friends to commit the old infidelities I’ve committed before. It’s very true that I’ve treated true love strangely and with disdain. But I swear by heaven, these moments when I’ve swerved aside have made my heart young again, and by trying out other people I’ve proved to myself that you’re the best person I love. Now I’ve finished with everything except for our love, which will have no end. I will no longer whet my appetite for new lovers, causing suffering to my old friend, the god of love to whom I’m now limiting myself. So welcome me back into your pure and loving heart; to me, you’re the next best thing to heaven.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: O for my sake do you with Fortune chide,$NEWLINE$The guilty goddess of my harmful deeds,$NEWLINE$That did not better for my life provide$NEWLINE$Than public means which public manners breeds.$NEWLINE$Thence comes it that my name receives a brand,$NEWLINE$And almost thence my nature is subdued$NEWLINE$To what it works in, like the dyer’s hand:$NEWLINE$Pity me then, and wish I were renewed,$NEWLINE$Whilst like a willing patient I will drink$NEWLINE$Potions of eisel 'gainst my strong infection;$NEWLINE$No bitterness that I will bitter think,$NEWLINE$Nor double penance, to correct correction.$NEWLINE$Pity me then, dear friend, and I assure ye,$NEWLINE$Ev'n that your pity is enough to cure me.
paragraphs.translated:
I know you curse my bad luck for having no better way to make a living than in front of the
public, which has had a bad effect on my morals and behavior. This is why I have a bad name, and coming into contact with the public so much has polluted my very nature, just like a cloth-dyer’s hand becomes stained with his dye. So take pity on me and hope that I can go back to being the way I would have been if I hadn’t been contaminated by the public; meanwhile, I’ll drink bitter medicines made of vinegar to cure myself of this infection. I won’t think that the medicine’s bitter no matter how bitter it is, nor will I protest at having to do double penance to try to undo the bad influence. So pity me, dear friend, and I assure you: Your pity alone is enough to cure me.$NEWLINE$public$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Your love and pity doth th' impression fill$NEWLINE$Which vulgar scandal stamped upon my brow;$NEWLINE$For what care I who calls me well or ill,$NEWLINE$So you o'er-green my bad, my good allow?$NEWLINE$You are my all the world, and I must strive$NEWLINE$To know my shames and praises from your tongue;$NEWLINE$None else to me, nor I to none alive,$NEWLINE$That my steeled sense or changes right or wrong.$NEWLINE$In so profound abysm I throw all care$NEWLINE$Of others' voices, that my adder’s sense$NEWLINE$To critic and to flatt’rer stoppèd are.$NEWLINE$Mark how with my neglect I do dispense:$NEWLINE$You are so strongly in my purpose bred$NEWLINE$That all the world besides methinks y'are dead.
paragraphs.translated:
(Continuing from Sonnet 111) Your love and pity make up for the damage popular opinion has done to my reputation, since what do I care who calls me good or bad as long as you gloss over what’s bad about me and acknowledge my good? You’re the entire world to me, and I have to strive to learn what’s good or bad about me from what you say. No one else matters to me, and I matter to no one else alive. Your
opinion is so powerful with me that it determines what’s right and wrong. I care so little about what other people say that it’s as if I threw their voices into a bottomless pit—that’s how deaf I am to their flattery and criticism. Notice how I disregard the fact that the rest of the world neglects me. You matter so much to me that you’re dead to the rest of the world.$NEWLINE$(Continuing from Sonnet 111)$NEWLINE$you$NEWLINE$Your$NEWLINE$opinion$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$is so powerful with me that it determines what’s right and wrong.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Since I left you, mine eye is in my mind,$NEWLINE$And that which governs me to go about$NEWLINE$Doth part his function, and is partly blind,$NEWLINE$Seems seeing, but effectually is out;$NEWLINE$For it no form delivers to the heart$NEWLINE$Of bird, of flow'r, or shape which it doth latch.$NEWLINE$Of his quick objects hath the mind no part,$NEWLINE$Nor his own vision holds what it doth catch;$NEWLINE$For if it see the rud’st or gentlest sight,$NEWLINE$The most sweet favor or deformèd’st creature,$NEWLINE$The mountain, or the sea, the day, or night,$NEWLINE$The crow, or dove, it shapes them to your feature.$NEWLINE$Incapable of more, replete with you,$NEWLINE$My most true mind thus makes mine untrue.
paragraphs.translated: Since I left you, I’m so absorbed in my own thoughts that I partly see where I’m going and partly don’t. For my vision doesn’t focus on the shapes of birds or flowers or anything else it lands on. My mind simply isn’t on the living things that my eyes show it, nor do I remember the things I see. For whether I see the rudest or gentlest sight, the sweetest-looking or the most deformed creature, the mountain or the sea, the day or the night, the crow or the dove, my vision shapes them so they look like you. Incapable of seeing anything else and filled with your image, my faithfulness to you is making me see everything wrongly.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Or whether doth my mind, being crowned with you,$NEWLINE$Drink up the monarch’s plague, this flattery?$NEWLINE$Or whether shall I say mine eye saith true,$NEWLINE$And that your love taught it this alchemy,$NEWLINE$To make of monsters and things indigest$NEWLINE$Such cherubins as your sweet self resemble,$NEWLINE$Creating every bad a perfect best$NEWLINE$As fast as objects to his beams assemble?$NEWLINE$O ’tis the first; ’tis flattery in my seeing,$NEWLINE$And my great mind most kingly drinks it up.$NEWLINE$Mine eye well knows what with his gust is greeing,$NEWLINE$And to his palate doth prepare the cup.$NEWLINE$If it be poisoned, ’tis the lesser sin$NEWLINE$That mine eye loves it and doth first begin.
paragraphs.translated: (Continuing from Sonnet 113) Is it the case that my mind, flattered by your love, has become susceptible to pleasurable delusions? Or is it the case that my eyes are seeing accurately, and my love for you has given me magical powers to turn monsters and shapeless things into angels that look like your sweet self, transforming every bad sight into the best and most perfect thing as fast as it comes into my field of vision? Oh, the first is true: My eyes are deluded, and my mind accepts these delusions like a king accepts flattery. My eye knows perfectly well what I like to see, and it shows me what it knows I’ll enjoy. Though its visions are poisoned by falsehood, my eye can be partially excused by the fact that it likes these false visions too and consumes them first, like a servant who tastes the king’s food to see if it’s poisoned.$NEWLINE$(Continuing from Sonnet 113)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Those lines that I before have writ do lie,$NEWLINE$Ev'n those that said I could not love you dearer.$NEWLINE$Yet then my judgment knew no reason why$NEWLINE$My most full flame should afterwards burn clearer.$NEWLINE$But reck'ning time, whose millioned accidents$NEWLINE$Creep in ’twixt vows, and change decrees of kings,$NEWLINE$Tan sacred beauty, blunt the sharp’st intents,$NEWLINE$Divert strong minds to the course of alt'ring things.$NEWLINE$Alas, why, fearing of time’s tyranny,$NEWLINE$Might I not then say, “Now I love you best,”$NEWLINE$When I was certain o'er incertainty,$NEWLINE$Crowning the present, doubting of the rest?$NEWLINE$Love is a babe; then might I not say so,$NEWLINE$To give full growth to that which still doth grow?
paragraphs.translated:
I lied in those poems I wrote before where I said I couldn’t love you any more than I did already. Back then I had no reason to think that my love, which was already burning intensely, could burn any brighter. Instead, I was depending on the fact that the passage of time—together with the millions of unexpected events that can come between lovers' promises and change even the decrees of kings—might darken a lover’s sacred beauty, take the edge off of a lover’s keenest intentions, and force the strongest minds to adapt to changing circumstances. Alas, why didn’t I say back then, when I was worried about time’s destructive power, “I love you best now”? I was so certain of my feelings despite the uncertainty, and I was ready to say my present happiness was complete, though I had doubts about everything to come.
Love itself is a baby, so wouldn’t it have been natural for me to have said that my love for you was fully grown, though it keeps growing?$NEWLINE$Love$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Let me not to the marriage of true minds$NEWLINE$Admit impediments. Love is not love$NEWLINE$Which alters when it alteration finds,$NEWLINE$Or bends with the remover to remove.$NEWLINE$O no, it is an ever-fixèd mark$NEWLINE$That looks on tempests and is never shaken;$NEWLINE$It is the star to every wand'ring bark,$NEWLINE$Whose worth’s unknown, although his height be taken.$NEWLINE$Love’s not time’s fool, though rosy lips and cheeks$NEWLINE$Within his bending sickle’s compass come:$NEWLINE$Love alters not with his brief hours and weeks,$NEWLINE$But bears it out even to the edge of doom.$NEWLINE$If this be error and upon me proved,$NEWLINE$I never writ, nor no man ever loved.
paragraphs.translated: I hope I may never acknowledge any reason why minds that truly love each other shouldn’t be joined together. Love isn’t really love if it changes when it sees the beloved change or if it disappears when the beloved leaves. Oh no, love is a constant and unchanging light that shines on storms without being shaken; it is the star that guides every wandering boat. And like a star, its value is beyond measure, though its height can be measured. Love is not under time’s power, though time has the power to destroy rosy lips and cheeks. Love does not alter with the passage of brief hours and weeks, but lasts until Doomsday. If I’m wrong about this and can be proven wrong, I never wrote, and no man ever loved.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Accuse me thus: that I have scanted all$NEWLINE$Wherein I should your great deserts repay,$NEWLINE$Forgot upon your dearest love to call,$NEWLINE$Whereto all bonds do tie me day by day;$NEWLINE$That I have frequent been with unknown minds,$NEWLINE$And giv'n to time your own dear purchased right;$NEWLINE$That I have hoisted sail to all the winds$NEWLINE$Which should transport me farthest from your sight.$NEWLINE$Book both my willfulness and errors down,$NEWLINE$And on just proof surmise accumulate.$NEWLINE$Bring me within the level of your frown,$NEWLINE$But shoot not at me in your wakened hate,$NEWLINE$Since my appeal says I did strive to prove$NEWLINE$The constancy and virtue of your love.
paragraphs.translated: Accuse me like this: Say that I’ve neglected every opportunity to repay the great obligation I owe you; that I’ve forgotten to invoke your precious love, though every day I’m more and more bound to you. Say that I’ve spent too much time with strangers, giving away the time that you have a right to spend with me. Say that I’ve let every wind blow me as far away as possible from you. Write a list of all the stubborn and wrong things I’ve done, and put together a lot of speculations about my other misdeeds based on what you already know. Get ready to frown at me, but don’t frown at me because of what I’ve done to awaken new hatred in you, since I did it all to test the constancy and strength of your love.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Like as to make our appetites more keen$NEWLINE$With eager compounds we our palate urge;$NEWLINE$As, to prevent our maladies unseen,$NEWLINE$We sicken to shun sickness when we purge;$NEWLINE$Ev'n so, being full of your ne'er-cloying sweetness,$NEWLINE$To bitter sauces did I frame my feeding;$NEWLINE$And, sick of welfare, found a kind of meetness$NEWLINE$To be diseased ere that there was true needing.$NEWLINE$Thus policy in love, t' anticipate$NEWLINE$The ills that were not, grew to faults assured,$NEWLINE$And brought to medicine a healthful state$NEWLINE$Which, rank of goodness, would by ill be cured;$NEWLINE$But thence I learn, and find the lesson true,$NEWLINE$Drugs poison him that so fell sick of you.
paragraphs.translated:
Just as we like to sharpen our appetites by eating pungent combinations of food or make ourselves vomit in order to ward off future illness, so, in the same way, because I was so full of your sweetness (not that it’s ever cloying), I decided to switch from you to a more bitter diet. And because I was tired of being so healthy, I decided it would be good to make myself
sick, using other people to keep from getting sick of you. With this wise relationship strategy, which I adopted in anticipation of problems that didn’t exist, I actually became used to cheating on you. I applied medicine to a relationship that was healthy to begin with, attempting to cure something totally good by applying evil to it. But I learned from this—and I think what I learned is true—that the drugs I used are poisonous to me, since I’m so lovesick over you.$NEWLINE$sick$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: What potions have I drunk of siren tears,$NEWLINE$Distilled from limbecks foul as hell within,$NEWLINE$Applying fears to hopes, and hopes to fears,$NEWLINE$Still losing when I saw myself to win!$NEWLINE$What wretched errors hath my heart committed,$NEWLINE$Whilst it hath thought itself so blessèd never!$NEWLINE$How have mine eyes out of their spheres been fitted$NEWLINE$In the distraction of this madding fever!$NEWLINE$O benefit of ill, now I find true$NEWLINE$That better is by evil still made better;$NEWLINE$And ruined love when it is built anew$NEWLINE$Grows fairer than at first, more strong, far greater.$NEWLINE$So I return rebuked to my content,$NEWLINE$And gain by ills thrice more than I have spent.
paragraphs.translated: (Continuing from Sonnet 118) I’ve given myself medicines that seemed seductively sweet but in reality were foul as hell. I forced myself to doubt the things I was hopeful about and to be hopeful about what I should have worried about, always losing just when I expected myself to win! My heart committed wretched errors right at the moment when I thought I had never been more blessed! My eyes have popped out of their sockets in the delirium of this fever! But, oh, the benefits that evil brings! Now I see it’s true that good things can be made even better through evil, and that when you ruin love and then rebuild it, it grows more beautiful than it was at first, as well as stronger and greater. So, having been rebuked for my mistake, I return to the person who makes me happy, and because of my evil deeds I get back three times what I spent.$NEWLINE$(Continuing from Sonnet 118)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: That you were once unkind befriends me now,$NEWLINE$And for that sorrow which I then did feel$NEWLINE$Needs must I under my transgression bow,$NEWLINE$Unless my nerves were brass or hammered steel.$NEWLINE$For if you were by my unkindness shaken,$NEWLINE$As I by yours, you’ve passed a hell of time,$NEWLINE$And I, a tyrant, have no leisure taken$NEWLINE$To weigh how once I suffered in your crime.$NEWLINE$O that our night of woe might have rememb’red$NEWLINE$My deepest sense, how hard true sorrow hits,$NEWLINE$And soon to you as you to me then tendered$NEWLINE$The humble salve which wounded bosoms fits!$NEWLINE$But that your trespass now becomes a fee;$NEWLINE$Mine ransoms yours, and yours must ransom me.
paragraphs.translated: The fact that you were once cruel to me helps me now. Because of the sorrow that you made me feel then, I would have to be made of steel not to be bowed down to the ground with guilt over how I’ve hurt you. For if you’ve felt my unkindness to you the way I felt yours to me, you’ve endured a time in hell and I’ve acted like a cruel tyrant, never taking the time to think about how I once suffered when you committed the same crime against me. Oh, how I wish that your earlier sorrow had reminded me of how hard true sorrow hits, so that I would have apologized to you as fast as you apologized to me, giving you the medicine that an injured heart needs most! But your earlier offense against me can now compensate you for what I’ve just done. My offense cancels out yours, and yours must cancel out mine.

paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: 'Tis better to be vile than vile esteemed,$NEWLINE$When not to be receives reproach of being,$NEWLINE$And the just pleasure lost which is so deemed$NEWLINE$Not by our feeling but by others' seeing.$NEWLINE$For why should others' false adulterate eyes$NEWLINE$Give salutation to my sportive blood?$NEWLINE$Or on my frailties why are frailer spies,$NEWLINE$Which in their wills count bad what I think good?$NEWLINE$No, I am that I am, and they that level$NEWLINE$At my abuses reckon up their own;$NEWLINE$I may be straight, though they themselves be bevel.$NEWLINE$By their rank thoughts my deeds must not be shown,$NEWLINE$Unless this general evil they maintain:$NEWLINE$All men are bad, and in their badness reign.
paragraphs.translated: It’s better to be vile than to have people think you’re vile, especially when they accuse you of being vile and you’re really not, and then you don’t even get to enjoy doing the thing that people say is vile but that you don’t think is. For why should people who are corrupt themselves get to wink knowingly at my lustful inclinations? And why should people who are even weaker than I pry into my weaknesses, deciding that what I think is good is bad? No, I am what I am, and the people who accuse me are only revealing their own corruptions. Maybe I’m straight, and they’re the ones who are crooked; you can’t measure my actions by their foul thoughts, unless they’re willing to believe that all men are bad and thrive in their badness.

paragraphs.original: Thy gift, thy tables, are within my brain$NEWLINE$Full charactered with lasting memory,$NEWLINE$Which shall above that idle rank remain$NEWLINE$Beyond all date, ev'n to eternity;$NEWLINE$Or at the least, so long as brain and heart$NEWLINE$Have faculty by nature to subsist;$NEWLINE$Till each to razed oblivion yield his part$NEWLINE$Of thee, thy record never can be missed.$NEWLINE$That poor retention could not so much hold,$NEWLINE$Nor need I tallies thy dear love to score;$NEWLINE$Therefore to give them from me was I bold,$NEWLINE$To trust those tables that receive thee more;$NEWLINE$To keep an adjunct to remember thee$NEWLINE$Were to import forgetfulness in me.
paragraphs.translated:
In my mind, I’ve already filled up the
blank book you gave me with words that will remain in my memory longer than they would in that flimsy little book. In my memory, what I wrote about you will outlast any date, even to eternity. Or at least this record of you won’t be lost as long as my brain and heart survive—until each of them is forced to give up its part of you and pass into oblivion. That poor little notebook couldn’t hold as much as my memory can, and I have no need to keep notes to remember how much I love you. Therefore I was bold enough to give away your notebook, trusting in my own memory to keep a better record of you. For me to use an aid to remember you would imply that I’m forgetful.$NEWLINE$blank book$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: No! Time, thou shalt not boast that I do change.$NEWLINE$Thy pyramids built up with newer might$NEWLINE$To me are nothing novel, nothing strange;$NEWLINE$They are but dressings of a former sight.$NEWLINE$Our dates are brief, and therefore we admire$NEWLINE$What thou dost foist upon us that is old,$NEWLINE$And rather make them born to our desire$NEWLINE$Than think that we before have heard them told.$NEWLINE$Thy registers and thee I both defy,$NEWLINE$Not wond'ring at the present nor the past;$NEWLINE$For thy recórds and what we see doth lie,$NEWLINE$Made more or less by thy continual haste.$NEWLINE$This I do vow and this shall ever be:$NEWLINE$I will be true, despite thy scythe and thee.
paragraphs.translated: No! Time, you’re not going to boast that I change. These new enormous buildings that are being erected don’t seem novel or strange to me at all—they’re just replicas of what’s existed before. Our lives are brief, and therefore we admire whatever is old, acting like it was made just for us rather than admitting we’ve heard it described before. I defy you and your records. I’m not interested in the present or the past, because both your records and the things we see around us lie. They are raised up and destroyed by your continual swift passage. I make this vow, and it shall always be true: I will be faithful despite you and your destructive power.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT

paragraphs.original: If my dear love were but the child of state,$NEWLINE$It might for Fortune’s bastard be unfathered,$NEWLINE$As subject to time’s love or to time’s hate,$NEWLINE$Weeds among weeds, or flow'rs with flowers gathered.$NEWLINE$No, it was builded far from accident;$NEWLINE$It suffers not in smiling pomp, nor falls$NEWLINE$Under the blow of thrallèd discontent,$NEWLINE$Whereto th' inviting time our fashion calls.$NEWLINE$It fears not policy, that heretic,$NEWLINE$Which works on leases of short numb’red hours.$NEWLINE$But all alone stands hugely politic,$NEWLINE$That it nor grows with heat nor drowns with showers.$NEWLINE$To this I witness call the fools of time,$NEWLINE$Which die for goodness, who have lived for crime.
paragraphs.translated: If my great love for you had simply been created by circumstances, it might be rejected as illegitimate because changing circumstances could destroy it. It would be subject to whatever’s in fashion at the moment, rejected with worthless things or plucked up with other fashionable flowers. No, my love was created where it can’t be touched by the unpredictability of events. It’s not helped by the approval of authority, nor is it crushed along with the malcontents who resist authority, as these times tempt us to do. My love isn’t afraid of the political scheming and conniving engaged in by immoral people, which only has a short term effect, but stands by itself, independent and enormously wise, neither growing during times of pleasure nor killed by misfortune. To attest to what I’m saying, I call as witnesses all those fools who died repentant and seeking goodness after living lives dedicated to crime.

paragraphs.original: Were’t ought to me I bore the canopy,$NEWLINE$With my extern the outward honoring,$NEWLINE$Or laid great bases for eternity,$NEWLINE$Which prove more short than waste or ruining?$NEWLINE$Have I not seen dwellers on form and favor$NEWLINE$Lose all and more by paying too much rent,$NEWLINE$For compound sweet forgoing simple savor,$NEWLINE$Pitiful thrivers, in their gazing spent?$NEWLINE$No, let me be obsequious in thy heart,$NEWLINE$And take thou my oblation, poor but free,$NEWLINE$Which is not mixed with seconds, knows no art,$NEWLINE$But mutual render, only me for thee.$NEWLINE$Hence, thou suborned informer! A true soul$NEWLINE$When most impeached stands least in thy control.
paragraphs.translated:
Would it matter at all to me to carry the ceremonial canopy of a monarch in a procession, honoring the display of power with my appearance? Or would I think it worthwhile to lay the foundations of supposedly eternal monuments, which actually last only as long as decay or ruin permit? Haven’t I seen those who focus on appearances and covet the favors of the powerful lose everything, and more than everything, by spending too much on their obsessions? Such pitiful strivers give up simple pleasures for the sake of lavish meals, using up all their resources on their fickle desires. No, I shall be obedient and faithful to you only, and you shall accept my offering. It is simple but freely given, contains nothing second-rate, no unnecessary additions, only mutual surrender: myself for yourself. Get out of here, you
paid spy: When a faithful person like I am is accused, someone like you has no power over them.$NEWLINE$paid spy$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: O thou, my lovely boy, who in thy pow'r$NEWLINE$Dost hold time’s fickle glass, his sickle hour,$NEWLINE$Who hast by waning grown, and therein show’st$NEWLINE$Thy lovers withering, as thy sweet self grow’st—$NEWLINE$If nature, sovereign mistress over wrack,$NEWLINE$As thou goest onwards still will pluck thee back,$NEWLINE$She keeps thee to this purpose: that her skill$NEWLINE$May time disgrace, and wretched minute kill.$NEWLINE$Yet fear her, O thou minion of her pleasure;$NEWLINE$She may detain, but not still keep, her treasure.$NEWLINE$Her audit, though delayed, answered must be,$NEWLINE$And her quietus is to render thee.$NEWLINE$(     )$NEWLINE$(     )
paragraphs.translated: Oh, my lovely boy, you seem to have power over time itself, immune to its capacity to cut things down. If nature, which has power over destruction, has chosen to hold you back from decay, she’s doing so for this reason: to disgrace time and kill its effects. Yet in spite of this, you should fear her, though you’re nature’s best-loved pet. She can preserve you for a time, but she can’t keep you, her treasure, always. Nature will eventually be called to offer her accounts, and though she can delay this, she has to do it, and the way she’ll pay her debt to time is with you. (  )$NEWLINE$(       )$NEWLINE$(       )$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: In the old age black was not counted fair,$NEWLINE$Or if it were, it bore not beauty’s name.$NEWLINE$But now is black beauty’s successive heir,$NEWLINE$And beauty slandered with a bastard shame.$NEWLINE$For since each hand hath put on nature’s pow'r,$NEWLINE$Fairing the foul with art’s false borrowed face,$NEWLINE$Sweet beauty hath no name, no holy bow'r,$NEWLINE$But is profaned, if not lives in disgrace.$NEWLINE$Therefore my mistress' eyes are raven black,$NEWLINE$Her eyes so suited, and they mourners seem$NEWLINE$At such who, not born fair, no beauty lack,$NEWLINE$Sland'ring creation with a false esteem.$NEWLINE$Yet so they mourn, becoming of their woe,$NEWLINE$That every tongue says beauty should look so.
paragraphs.translated: In the olden days, dark complexions weren’t considered attractive or, if they were, no one called them beautiful. But now darkness is officially accepted as beautiful, and the fair complexions that used to be called beautiful have gotten a bad reputation. For since everyone has seized the power to make themselves beautiful (which used to belong to nature), and ugly people can be beautiful by artificial means, no one can legitimately be called beautiful. Beauty has no special home but is commonplace or even lives in disgrace. Therefore my mistress’s eyes are as black as a raven, well suited to today’s fashion, and in their blackness they seem to be lamenting those people who were born ugly but make themselves beautiful, giving beauty a bad name by faking it. But her black eyes lament so beautifully that everyone now says all beautiful eyes should look like hers.

Very often, when you (my greatest source of delight) play music by moving those wooden keys on the keyboard of the

paragraphs.translated: Even looking like you do, you’re as much of a tyrant as those women whose beauty makes them proud and cruel. There’s nothing black about you except your actions, and I think that’s the reason people spread this lie about your looks.

paragraphs.original: Thine eyes I love, and they, as pitying me,$NEWLINE$Knowing thy heart torment me with disdain,$NEWLINE$Have put on black, and loving mourners be,$NEWLINE$Looking with pretty ruth upon my pain;$NEWLINE$And truly, not the morning sun of heav'n$NEWLINE$Better becomes the gray cheeks of the east,$NEWLINE$Nor that full star that ushers in the ev'n$NEWLINE$Doth half that glory to the sober west,$NEWLINE$As those two mourning eyes become thy face.$NEWLINE$O let it then as well beseem thy heart$NEWLINE$To mourn for me, since mourning doth thee grace,$NEWLINE$And suit thy pity like in every part.$NEWLINE$Then will I swear beauty herself is black,$NEWLINE$And all they foul that thy complexion lack.
paragraphs.translated: I love your eyes, and they seem to pity me, knowing I’m tormented by your disdain. In black, they look like mourners at a funeral, gazing at my pain with pretty compassion. paragraphs.original: Beshrew that heart that makes my heart to groan$NEWLINE$For that deep wound it gives my friend and me;$NEWLINE$Is’t not enough to torture me alone,$NEWLINE$But slave to slavery my sweet’st friend must be?$NEWLINE$Me from myself thy cruel eye hath taken,$NEWLINE$And my next self thou harder hast engrossed;$NEWLINE$Of him, myself, and thee I am forsaken,$NEWLINE$A torment thrice threefold thus to be crossed.$NEWLINE$Prison my heart in thy steel bosom’s ward,$NEWLINE$But then my friend’s heart let my poor heart bail.$NEWLINE$Whoe'er keeps me, let my heart be his guard;$NEWLINE$Thou canst not then use rigor in my jail.$NEWLINE$And yet thou wilt, for I being pent in thee,$NEWLINE$Perforce am thine, and all that is in me.
paragraphs.translated: Curse you for making me suffer by hurting both my friend and me. Isn’t it enough to torture me alone without making my friend your slave too? Because of your cruel attractions I’m no longer my own man, but my friend, who’s like my second self, you’ve enslaved even more cruelly. paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.translated: (Continuing from Sonnet 133) So now I’ve admitted that he’s yours, and I’m legally bound to satisfy your desires too. paragraphs.translated: Love, you blind fool, what are you doing to my eyes that’s keeping them from accurately seeing what I look at? My eyes know what beauty is, and they see who has it, yet they decide that the worst woman is the best. Love, if my vision has been distorted because I look at her with too much bias, spending all my time staring at this woman who sleeps with every man, why have you used my misperceptions as a trap to fool my heart, so that I love the wrong person? Why should my heart think that she could belong to one man when my heart knows she’s available to the whole world? Or why should my eyes witness her promiscuity but act like it’s not true, putting a good face on an ugly truth? My heart and my eyes have been completely mistaken about the truth, and now they both love this unfaithful disease of a woman.$NEWLINE$Love$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: When my love swears that she is made of truth$NEWLINE$I do believe her, though I know she lies,$NEWLINE$That she might think me some untutored youth$NEWLINE$Unlearnèd in the world’s false subtleties.$NEWLINE$Thus vainly thinking that she thinks me young,$NEWLINE$Although she knows my days are past the best,$NEWLINE$Simply I credit her false speaking tongue;$NEWLINE$On both sides thus is simple truth suppressed.$NEWLINE$But wherefore says she not she is unjust?$NEWLINE$And wherefore say not I that I am old?$NEWLINE$O love’s best habit is in seeming trust,$NEWLINE$And age in love loves not t' have years told.$NEWLINE$Therefore I lie with her, and she with me,$NEWLINE$And in our faults by lies we flattered be.
paragraphs.translated: When my mistress swears that she’s completely truthful, I believe her even though I know she lies, so that she’ll think that I’m some naïve young man who’s ignorant about the world and the tricks people play. I pretend to stupidly believe her lies while fooling myself into thinking that she thinks I’m young, even though she knows I’m past my prime. In this way, both of us suppress the simple truth. But why doesn’t she say she’s a liar? And why don’t I say that I’m old? Oh, because it’s easiest to love someone who seems to be trustworthy, and old people who are in love hate to hear their age discussed. Therefore, I sleep with her, and she sleeps with me, and we both flatter ourselves by lying about each other’s faults.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: O call not me to justify the wrong$NEWLINE$That thy unkindness lays upon my heart.$NEWLINE$Wound me not with thine eye, but with thy tongue;$NEWLINE$Use pow'r with pow'r, and slay me not by art.$NEWLINE$Tell me thou lov’st elsewhére; but in my sight,$NEWLINE$Dear heart, forbear to glance thine eye aside.$NEWLINE$What need’st thou wound with cunning when thy might$NEWLINE$Is more than my o'er-pressed defense can bide?$NEWLINE$Let me excuse thee: Ah, my love well knows$NEWLINE$Her pretty looks have been mine enemies,$NEWLINE$And therefore from my face she turns my foes,$NEWLINE$That they elsewhére might dart their injuries.$NEWLINE$Yet do not so, but since I am near slain,$NEWLINE$Kill me outr'ght with looks, and rid my pain.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, don’t ask me to justify the cruel infidelities with which you have hurt me. Don’t hurt me by stealing glances at other men; hurt me by telling me about them to my face. Use your power openly, don’t kill me with subtle tricks. Tell me you love other people, but when you’re in my sight, dear heart, don’t glance at other men. Why would you need to hurt me with cunning, when your power over me is already too much for me to defend against? But I’ll make an excuse for you: Ah, my love knows perfectly well that her looks can kill me, so she looks away from me to kill my enemies instead. But don’t do that. Since I’m almost dead already, kill me outright with your looks, and put me out of my misery.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Be wise as thou art cruel; do not press$NEWLINE$My tongue-tied patience with too much disdain,$NEWLINE$Lest sorrow lend me words, and words express$NEWLINE$The manner of my pity-wanting pain.$NEWLINE$If I might teach thee wit, better it were,$NEWLINE$Though not to love, yet love, to tell me so,$NEWLINE$As testy sick men, when their deaths be near,$NEWLINE$No news but health from their physicians know.$NEWLINE$For if I should despair, I should grow mad,$NEWLINE$And in my madness might speak ill of thee.$NEWLINE$Now this ill-wresting world is grown so bad,$NEWLINE$Mad sland’rers by mad ears believèd be.$NEWLINE$That I may not be so, nor thou belied,$NEWLINE$Bear thine eyes straight, though thy proud heart go wide.
paragraphs.translated: Be as wise as you are cruel: Don’t torture me too much with your disdain, in case sorrow forces me to speak, and I express how pitiless you are in hurting me. If you’ll let me teach you some skill—it would be better if you told me you loved me even if you don’t, as when short-tempered patients close to death get only good news from their doctors. Because if I start to despair, I’ll go mad, and in my madness I might speak ill of you. This world has gotten so bad with its lies and rumors that crazy people believe the lies that crazy people tell. To prevent my going crazy and your being lied about, keep your eyes where they should be, even when your heart’s wandering where it wants.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: In faith, I do not love thee with mine eyes,$NEWLINE$For they in thee a thousand errors note;$NEWLINE$But ’tis my heart that loves what they despise,$NEWLINE$Who in despite of view is pleased to dote.$NEWLINE$Nor are mine ears with thy tongue’s tune delighted,$NEWLINE$Nor tender feeling to base touches prone,$NEWLINE$Nor taste, nor smell, desire to be invited$NEWLINE$To any sensual feast with thee alone.$NEWLINE$But my five wits, nor my five senses, can$NEWLINE$Dissuade one foolish heart from serving thee,$NEWLINE$Who leaves unswayed the likeness of a man,$NEWLINE$Thy proud heart’s slave and vassal wretch to be.$NEWLINE$Only my plague thus far I count my gain,$NEWLINE$That she that makes me sin awards me pain.
paragraphs.translated: I swear, I don’t love you with my eyes: They notice a thousand flaws in you. Rather, it’s my heart that loves what my eyes despise; despite what you look like, my heart dotes on you. Nor are my ears delighted by the sound of your voice. Nor do I want to abuse my delicate sense of touch by groping you. Nor do my sense of taste or smell want to be invited to any feast of the senses in which you’re the main course. But neither my brain nor my five senses can dissuade my foolish heart from being your servant. My body stands here like an empty shell with no one to control it, while my heart goes off to be your slave and wretched property. I gain one thing from being plagued with love for this woman: The same woman who’s making me sin rewards me with pain.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Love is my sin, and thy dear virtue hate,$NEWLINE$Hate of my sin, grounded on sinful loving.$NEWLINE$O but with mine compare thou thine own state,$NEWLINE$And thou shalt find it merits not reproving;$NEWLINE$Or, if it do, not from those lips of thine,$NEWLINE$That have profaned their scarlet ornaments$NEWLINE$And sealed false bonds of love as oft as mine,$NEWLINE$Robbed others' beds' revénues of their rents.$NEWLINE$Be it lawful I love thee as thou lov’st those$NEWLINE$Whom thine eyes woo as mine impórtune thee.$NEWLINE$Root pity in thy heart, that when it grows,$NEWLINE$Thy pity may deserve to pitied be.$NEWLINE$If thou dost seek to have what thou dost hide,$NEWLINE$By self-example mayst thou be denied.
paragraphs.translated: Loving you is my sin, and your precious virtue consists in hating my sin, a hate grounded in your own sinful loving. But compare my moral state with your own, and you’ll see I don’t deserve to be reprimanded, or if I do, not from those lips of yours, which you’ve dishonored by using too much. Your lips have kissed as many people and made as many false promises as mine have, and both of us have cheated on our partners, giving away sexual favors where they don’t belong. If I may be allowed to love you the same way you love those other men whom you seduce with your glances, have a little pity for me; then you’ll deserve to be pitied yourself. If you want people to take pity on you and sleep with you, but you don’t show pity for me, you might be turned down because of your own example.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Lo, as a careful housewife runs to catch$NEWLINE$One of her feathered creatures broke away,$NEWLINE$Sets down her babe and makes all swift dispatch$NEWLINE$In púrsuit of the thing she would have stay;$NEWLINE$Whilst her neglected child holds her in chase,$NEWLINE$Cries to catch her whose busy care is bent$NEWLINE$To follow that which flies before her face,$NEWLINE$Not prizing her poor infant’s discontent:$NEWLINE$So run’st thou after that which flies from thee,$NEWLINE$Whilst I, thy babe, chase thee afar behind.$NEWLINE$But if thou catch thy hope, turn back to me,$NEWLINE$And play the mother’s part, kiss me, be kind.$NEWLINE$So will I pray that thou mayst have thy Will,$NEWLINE$If thou turn back and my loud crying still.
paragraphs.translated:
Like an anxious housewife who runs to catch one of her chickens that’s run away, setting down her baby to follow it while her neglected child chases after her and cries out to get her attention—she focusing all of her mind on trying to catch the chicken that’s flying in front of her, not caring about her infant’s distress—in the same way, you’re running after someone who’s running from you, while I, your baby, chase after you from far behind. But if you catch the one you’re hoping for, turn back to me and act like a mother. Kiss me, be kind. If you’ll turn back and stop my loud crying, I’ll pray that you’ll get to have your
Will.$NEWLINE$Will$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Two loves I have, of comfort and despair,$NEWLINE$Which, like two spirits, do suggest me still;$NEWLINE$The better angel is a man right fair,$NEWLINE$The worser spirit a woman colored ill.$NEWLINE$To win me soon to hell, my female evil$NEWLINE$Tempteth my better angel from my side,$NEWLINE$And would corrupt my saint to be a devil,$NEWLINE$Wooing his purity with her foul pride.$NEWLINE$And whether that my angel be turned fiend$NEWLINE$Suspect I may, but not directly tell;$NEWLINE$But being both from me both to each friend,$NEWLINE$I guess one angel in another’s hell.$NEWLINE$Yet this shall I ne'er know, but live in doubt,$NEWLINE$Till my bad angel fire my good one out.
paragraphs.translated:
I love two people. One comforts me and the other makes me despair. Like two spirits both constantly point me in different directions. The better angel is a beautiful, fair-haired man. The bad one is an evil-looking woman. To help put me in hell sooner, my evil female tempts my angel away from my side. She hopes to make my saint into a devil, seducing him to impure acts in her foul and self-assured way. And though I can suspect him, there’s no way I can tell directly whether my angel has turned into a fiend. But since the two of them are away from me and friendly with each other, I’m guessing that one angel is inside the other—and in hell with her. Yet I’ll never know this for sure, instead living in doubt until my bad angel
fires the good one out of hell.$NEWLINE$fires$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Those lips that love’s own hand did make$NEWLINE$Breathed forth the sound that said “I hate”$NEWLINE$To me that languished for her sake;$NEWLINE$But when she saw my woeful state,$NEWLINE$Straight in her heart did mercy come,$NEWLINE$Chiding that tongue that, ever sweet,$NEWLINE$Was used in giving gentle doom,$NEWLINE$And taught it thus anew to greet:$NEWLINE$“I hate” she altered with an end$NEWLINE$That followed it as gentle day$NEWLINE$Doth follow night, who like a fiend$NEWLINE$From heav'n to hell is flown away.$NEWLINE$“I hate” from hate away she threw,$NEWLINE$And saved my life, saying “not you.”
paragraphs.translated: Those lips that look like they were made by the goddess of love herself breathed forth the words, “I hate”—and she was talking to me, the man who’s pining with love for her. But when she saw how unhappy she’d made me, mercy came into her heart and she chided her sweet tongue, which is usually so gentle and merciful, and taught it to speak something else to me. She changed “I hate” by adding a few words the way day follows night, that fiend flying from heaven to hell: She took hatred away from “I hate,” saving my life with “not you.”

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original:
Poor soul, the center of my sinful earth,$NEWLINE$[
Thrall to] these rebel pow'rs that thee array,$NEWLINE$Thrall to$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$Why dost thou pine within and suffer dearth,$NEWLINE$Painting thy outward walls so costly gay?$NEWLINE$Why so large cost, having so short a lease,$NEWLINE$Dost thou upon thy fading mansion spend?$NEWLINE$Shall worms, inheritors of this excess,$NEWLINE$Eat up thy charge? Is this thy body’s end?$NEWLINE$Then, soul, live thou upon thy servant’s loss,$NEWLINE$And let that pine to aggravate thy store;$NEWLINE$Buy terms divine in selling hours of dross;$NEWLINE$Within be fed, without be rich no more.$NEWLINE$So shalt thou feed on death, that feeds on men,$NEWLINE$And death once dead, there’s no more dying then.
paragraphs.translated: My poor soul, you’re the very center of this sinful world, my body, which rebels against you. Why do you starve yourself inside me and suffer from a shortage of supplies while you dress your outside in such expensive finery? Why do you spend so much on your aging body when you get to occupy it for such a short time? All of this expenditure on a body that is eventually going to be eaten by the worms—do you want what you spend to be devoured by worms? Is this what your body was intended for? In that case, soul, feed yourself by starving your body; let it pine for food while you accumulate the riches. Buy time in heaven by giving up worthless time wasted on earth. Feed your inner self; let your body be poor. By starving your body, you will eat up death, which eats up men, and once death is dead, there’s no more dying then.$NEWLINE$it$NEWLINE$you

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: My love is as a fever, longing still$NEWLINE$For that which longer nurseth the disease,$NEWLINE$Feeding on that which doth preserve the ill,$NEWLINE$Th' uncertain sickly appetite to please.$NEWLINE$My reason, the physician to my love,$NEWLINE$Angry that his prescriptions are not kept,$NEWLINE$Hath left me, and I desp'rate now approve$NEWLINE$Desire is death, which physic did except.$NEWLINE$Past cure I am, now reason is past care,$NEWLINE$And frantic mad with evermore unrest,$NEWLINE$My thoughts and my discourse as madmen’s are,$NEWLINE$At random from the truth vainly expressed;$NEWLINE$For I have sworn thee fair and thought thee bright,$NEWLINE$Who art as black as hell, as dark as night.
paragraphs.translated: My love is like a fever, always making me yearn for what will prolong my disease. It lives on whatever will preserve the illness, in order to prop up my fickle desire. My reasoning has acted as doctor and treated my love, but then it left me because I wasn’t following its instructions. Now that I’m finally desperate enough, I realize that sexual desire, which was against the doctor’s orders, is lethal. Now that my mind is past caring, I’m past the point where I can be cured, and I’ve gone frantically crazy and grown increasingly restless. My thoughts and speech are like a madman’s, pointlessly expressing random untruths. For I have sworn that you’re beautiful and thought you radiant when you’re actually as black as hell and as dark as night.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: O me! what eyes hath love put in my head,$NEWLINE$Which have no correspondence with true sight!$NEWLINE$Or, if they have, where is my judgment fled,$NEWLINE$That censures falsely what they see aright?$NEWLINE$If that be fair whereon my false eyes dote,$NEWLINE$What means the world to say it is not so?$NEWLINE$If it be not, then love doth well denote$NEWLINE$Love’s eye is not so true as all men’s: no,$NEWLINE$How can it? O how can love’s eye be true,$NEWLINE$That is so vexed with watching and with tears?$NEWLINE$No marvel then, though I mistake my view;$NEWLINE$The sun itself sees not till heaven clears.$NEWLINE$O cunning love! With tears thou keep’st me blind,$NEWLINE$Lest eyes well seeing thy foul faults should find.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, me! What kind of eyes has love put into my head that I don’t see anything accurately? Or if my eyes do see correctly, what’s happened to my judgment to make me wrongly criticize what they see? If the woman I love to look at is beautiful, why does the rest of the world say she’s not? If she’s not, then a person in love doesn’t see as accurately as others. No—how can a lover see right? Oh, how can a lover’s eye work properly when it’s so distressed by staying awake and crying? It’s no wonder then that I’m wrong about what I see; the sun itself doesn’t see anything until the sky is clear. Oh, ingenious love, you keep me blind with tears so I won’t discover my lover’s foul faults, as I would if my eyes worked properly.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Canst thou, O cruel, say I love thee not,$NEWLINE$When I against myself with thee partake?$NEWLINE$Do I not think on thee, when I forgot$NEWLINE$Am of myself, all, tyrant, for thy sake?$NEWLINE$Who hateth thee that I do call my friend?$NEWLINE$On whom frown’st thou that I do fawn upon?$NEWLINE$Nay, if thou lour’st on me, do I not spend$NEWLINE$Revenge upon myself with present moan?$NEWLINE$What merit do I in myself respect,$NEWLINE$That is so proud thy service to despise,$NEWLINE$When all my best doth worship thy defect,$NEWLINE$Commanded by the motion of thine eyes?$NEWLINE$But, love, hate on, for now I know thy mind;$NEWLINE$Those that can see thou lov’st, and I am blind.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, you cruel woman, can you say I don’t love you when I take sides with you against myself? Don’t I think about you even when I’ve forgotten about myself—and all for your sake, you tyrant? Who hates you that I would call my friend? Who do you frown at that I grovel on and flatter? No—if you scowl at me, don’t I immediately punish myself by moaning? Which quality do I see in myself that would make me too proud to be your servant? All of the best in me worships the worst in you, and you can command me with a glance. But, my love, go on hating me, because now I know your mind. You love people who can see, and I’m blind.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: O from what pow'r hast thou this pow'rful might,$NEWLINE$With insufficiency my heart to sway,$NEWLINE$To make me give the lie to my true sight,$NEWLINE$And swear that brightness doth not grace the day?$NEWLINE$Whence hast thou this becoming of things ill,$NEWLINE$That in the very refuse of thy deeds$NEWLINE$There is such strength and warrantise of skill$NEWLINE$That in my mind thy worst all best exceeds?$NEWLINE$Who taught thee how to make me love thee more,$NEWLINE$The more I hear and see just cause of hate?$NEWLINE$O, though I love what others do abhor,$NEWLINE$With others thou shouldst not abhor my state.$NEWLINE$If thy unworthiness raised love in me,$NEWLINE$More worthy I to be beloved of thee.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, what is the source of this mighty power you have, which controls my affections despite your inadequacies, making me disbelieve what my eyes truly see until I’m so turned around I swear that daylight isn’t bright? Where did you get this capacity to make bad things look good in you, to perform the most worthless actions so skillfully that I think your worst is better than anyone else’s best? Who taught you how to make me love you more, the more I hear and see good reasons to hate you? Oh, even though I love what other people despise, you shouldn’t despise my love the way other people do. Since your unworthiness made me love you, I’m the person who deserves your love.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Love is too young to know what conscience is,$NEWLINE$Yet who knows not conscience is born of love?$NEWLINE$Then, gentle cheater, urge not my amiss,$NEWLINE$Lest guilty of my faults thy sweet self prove;$NEWLINE$For, thou betraying me, I do betray$NEWLINE$My nobler part to my gross body’s treason.$NEWLINE$My soul doth tell my body that he may$NEWLINE$Triumph in love—flesh stays no father reason,$NEWLINE$But, rising at thy name, doth point out thee$NEWLINE$As his triumphant prize—proud of this pride,$NEWLINE$He is contented thy poor drudge to be,$NEWLINE$To stand in thy affairs, fall by thy side.$NEWLINE$No want of conscience hold it that I call$NEWLINE$Her “love” for whose dear love I rise and fall.
paragraphs.translated: Cupid is too young to know right from wrong, but doesn’t everybody know that love is what gives you a conscience? In that case, gentle cheater, don’t criticize me too harshly for my mistake, because your sweet self might turn out to be guilty of the same faults. Because you betray me, I betray my soul to my dumb, rebellious body. My soul tells my body that it can have its way in love. My flesh doesn’t wait to hear any more, but at the sound of your name it rises up and points you out as its prize. My flesh, proud of having you, is happy to be your poor worker, to stand up to do your business and fall down beside you afterward. Do not assume my conscience is lacking just because the woman I call “love” makes my flesh rise and fall for her love.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: In loving thee thou know’st I am forsworn;$NEWLINE$But thou art twice forsworn to me love swearing,$NEWLINE$In act thy bed-vow broke and new faith torn,$NEWLINE$In vowing new hate after new love bearing.$NEWLINE$But why of two oaths' breach do I accuse thee,$NEWLINE$When I break twenty? I am perjured most,$NEWLINE$For all my vows are oaths but to misuse thee,$NEWLINE$And all my honest faith in thee is lost;$NEWLINE$For I have sworn deep oaths of thy deep kindness,$NEWLINE$Oaths of thy love, thy truth, thy constancy,$NEWLINE$And, to enlighten thee, gave eyes to blindness,$NEWLINE$Or made them swear against the thing they see.$NEWLINE$For I have sworn thee fair: more perjured eye,$NEWLINE$To swear against the truth so foul a lie.
paragraphs.translated: I know I’m breaking a promise by loving you, but you, swearing you love me, are breaking two promises: cheating on your husband by leaving his bed, then breaking your promise to your new lover by vowing to hate him. But why am I accusing you of breaking two oaths when I break twenty? I am perjured the most, because all of my vows are only made to mislead and exploit you; I’m no longer true to you. For I have sworn great oaths about how kind you are, oaths about your love, your faithfulness, your constancy. And to make you look better I blinded myself, swearing to the opposite of what I actually saw. For I have sworn that you are beautiful; my eye is doubly a liar, offering such a foul lie after swearing to tell the truth.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Cupid laid by his brand and fell asleep.$NEWLINE$A maid of Dian’s this advantage found,$NEWLINE$And his love-kindling fire did quickly steep$NEWLINE$In a cold valley-fountain of that ground,$NEWLINE$Which borrowed from this holy fire of love$NEWLINE$A dateless lively heat, still to endure,$NEWLINE$And grew a seething bath, which yet men prove$NEWLINE$Against strange maladies a sovereign cure.$NEWLINE$But at my mistress' eye love’s brand new fired,$NEWLINE$The boy for trial needs would touch my breast;$NEWLINE$I, sick withal, the help of bath desired,$NEWLINE$And thither hied, a sad distempered guest,$NEWLINE$But found no cure; the bath for my help lies$NEWLINE$Where Cupid got new fire—my mistress' eye.
paragraphs.translated:
Cupid put down his torch and fell asleep. One of the nymphs who serve
Diana took advantage of this situation and quickly plunged Cupid’s love-inducing flame in a nearby cold spring, which thus acquired a never-ending heat and became a bubbling hot bath that men still use to cure diseases. But at a glance from my mistress, Cupid’s torch fired up again, and Cupid decided to test whether his torch was working by touching my heart with it. I became
sick with love and wanted the bath to ease my discomfort. I went to the spring as a sad, sick guest but found no cure. The only thing that could help me is the thing that gave Cupid his new fire: a glance from my mistress’s eye.$NEWLINE$Diana$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$sick with love$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: The little love-god lying once asleep$NEWLINE$Laid by his side his heart-inflaming brand,$NEWLINE$Whilst many nymphs that vowed chaste life to keep$NEWLINE$Came tripping by; but in her maiden hand$NEWLINE$The fairest votary took up that fire,$NEWLINE$Which many legions of true hearts had warmed;$NEWLINE$And so the general of hot desire$NEWLINE$Was, sleeping, by a virgin hand disarmed.$NEWLINE$This brand she quenchèd in a cool well by,$NEWLINE$Which from love’s fire took heat perpetual,$NEWLINE$Growing a bath and healthful remedy$NEWLINE$For men diseased; but I, my mistress' thrall,$NEWLINE$Came there for cure, and this by that I prove:$NEWLINE$Love’s fire heats water; water cools not love.
paragraphs.translated: Once, while sleeping, little Cupid put down his love-inducing torch while many of Diana’s nymphs, who had all made lifelong vows of chastity, came tripping by. But the most beautiful of Diana’s nymphs picked up that fire that had warmed the hearts of legions of faithful lovers. In this fashion, the commander of hot desire was disarmed by the hand of a virgin as he was sleeping. She quenched this torch in a cool spring nearby, and the spring took a perpetual heat from love’s fire. It turned into a hot bath and healthy remedy for diseased men. But when I, enslaved by my mistress, went to the bath to be cured, this is what I learned: Love’s fire heats water, but water doesn’t cool love.
